DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

Sr. Philips
Residential School
Quarterly Returns
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. Where owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, posting it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paling it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance exceeding the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, should any grant be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. 4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days of residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days of residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the rate fixed for the quarter's grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. 6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. February 26, 1934

Mrs. J. L. Sutherland,
Acting Dept. of Indian Education

Dear Mrs. Sutherland,

Several weeks ago we received your kindly prompt answer to our request for infirmary supplies. I delayed our grateful acknowledgment to bring it nearer the date of our March Class Requisite List.

I had felt it my duty to ask for the infirmary supplies but had hardly hoped to receive all at once, though all were so needed. I can only assure you of our sincere gratitude, adding also an assurance of our careful attention to each helpful article received, in particular to the pharmacy scales and very complete Nurse's Kit. The one thing missing—a simple Medical Book—will come at some future date perhaps? If so, may we choose our author, it being understood that a small, handy aid will suffice?

In regard to your copy of Inspector Sparkes report of his visit Oct. 25, 1933 (your—17-3-6)—we thank you for acquainting us with his desires and suggestions.
In opening the January term we began new work which we believe will lead up to "the development of pupil initiative," he mentioned. We have added a drawing and painting period and have begun real modelling in plasticine, familiar objects, scenes, and relief maps. A third period is the Sunday Reading Hour—silent reading of interesting story books.

Our object was to give our children here the same advantages as found in older schools under our control, but we hope these advances made before knowing of Mrs. Parker's wishes may be found satisfactory by you for the present. We shall gladly receive further instructions from you upon this subject.

A consequence remains—a rather long list of requisites to put our plans into practice. As to reading, a library was begun two or three years ago but we need more books. We shall ask for a few on each Class Requisite list, but today I venture to enclose a list of books not found in school supply catalogues. We shall be most grateful for any number of them, as you feel cannot be afforded at this time. We have placed what we desire most, first.

Once more expressing our very sincere gratitude for favors received, I remain

Respectfully yours,

Sister Mary H. Charles,
Missionary Oblate

Honorable and dear Sir,

I venture to address to you a personal request that I must add at once—has thus been made by me and refused by the Department through shortage of funds or lack of understanding.

Our Reverend Principal has a very fond old "Remington" which certainly much has been given second-hand as our school was opened only eight years ago. Nevertheless I should be very glad to have this old typewriter if the Department would send a better one—not necessarily new—for the office.

I have already explained to the Department how our teachers are constantly in care of our pupils beyond class hours, either at play, in refectory or dormitory, and have therefore little time for class preparation. I could help them greatly by making copies of class work, songs, hymns etc., but it is not at all convenient for me to go to the office to type. You may judge the sincerity of my request made a fourth time.

Do you think you could procure this favor for us? If so, do you wish me to make out the usual three copies of my request to be sent through our agent, Mr. Ostrander?

Ottawa, January 23rd, 1941.

Rev. Sir:

With reference to your requisition dated the 16th instant, for classroom material for the St. Philip's Indian Residential School, I would advise you that the articles considered necessary have been ordered from the Government Stationery Office and will be shipped in due course. Included in the shipment is a number of books for supplementary reading purposes.

It is noted that you request 12 copies Health Stories, Book I; 12 copies Book II and 12 copies Book III. We do not supply Health Stories to Indian Schools. Instead of these books, we are supplying one copy Dent's Health Workbook and one copy Success and Health, which we have in stock. Success and Health is in use in practically all Indian schools and has been found very suitable for Indian pupils. Owing to the necessity for strict economy, it is felt that the teachers at your school could get along satisfactorily by using Success and Health as a Hand Book. No doubt, Dent's Health Workbook will prove useful in Grades 4, 5 and 6.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Ottawa, August 31st, 1944.

Dear Father Tetrault:

I am in receipt of a requisition dated the 4th instant for supplies for the St. Philip's Indian Residential School. I presume that you have already received a large portion of the original requisition of January 5th. When this requisition was received, we ordered from the Government Stationery Office all the items we allow or can obtain at the present time.

We ordered 16 boxes white chalk and if you have not received all of this you will, no doubt, receive the full quantity some time soon. Only 6 copies of 'Book of Boys and Girls Around the World' were ordered as we consider this number is sufficient. It is intended for supplementary work only. Only 6 copies of 'Diagnostic Tests and Remedial Exercises in Reading' were ordered, as we also consider this number sufficient. Twelve boxes of pastels were ordered and, if available, will be supplied. We also ordered the wax crayons, coloured cardboard, water colour refills, stamp pad ink, small envelopes, coloured chalk and 1 - 18" metal edge ruler. As stated above, if these items have not already reached you, they will go forward as soon as they can be secured. As you are aware, no doubt, it is extremely difficult to secure these articles in large quantities due to conditions beyond our control.

We will submit a new requisition for 'Bible Stories for Little Children', 'New Geographies' and for 24 Workbooks to accompany 'Playmates'. The other articles such as reeds and raffia cannot be secured at the present time.

The Indian Agent was authorized on March 31st to purchase the articles required for the vocational training class. We are writing to him today, and I suggest that you consult him.

Yours truly,

Rev. P.E. Tetrault, O.M.I.,

General Superintendent of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Mr. Morris,

As we were expecting your visit in St Philip's we delayed our letter, but as the days go by so quickly we come to expose you our great need, assured that a powerful friend like you will understand and grant us our legitimate desire.

Last fall we received from Ottawa 36 bible stories at .50¢ each. After a careful examination of the book, Father said they were not for us Catholics. So we just put them aside waiting for informations to send them back.

We received lately from Ginn Company the name of Learning Aids Charts; for which we are in very great need. The chart we possess was given in 1928 at the school opening and has been a perfect aid to the teachers. Now the printed method is changed and is highly recommended by the Inspectors, so we can not use the old chart any more.

Here comes in our idea. We thought to return the Bible Stories and to have instead the two charts and cards for the same price. But as it is a very delicate matter we are inquiring for your help to know at which address we should return our Bible Stories and have the charts forwarded to us.

Inclose the list from Ginn Co. Thanking you in advance for all the trouble we are giving you.

We remain yours ever grateful

Sisters of Saint Philip's Sask.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

December 20, 1951

Mr. P. Phelan,
Chief of Education Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa

Dear Mr. Phelan:

We are thankful for the Reference books sent in by the Department lately, and beg to take this opportunity to enquire about a requisition for School material forwarded through Pelley's Indian Agency last September and labelled "Urgently needed" because of an error made by the teachers in the preceding list of school material. This tardy invoice was required to help cover both the school year and exhibition programs.

Do you think it would be possible to have at least the scribblers sent in first and have the other items follow in a near future?

We had also requested for a radio-phonograph and a complete set of Class room records such as mentioned last year in the Indian Bulletin as the best teaching aid for music appreciation, singing and folk dancing in the Grades.

Trusting all this will be taken into consideration,

I extend to you my best of Christmas wishes and of success for the coming year,

And remain very sincerely yours,

[Signature]

As instructed by your official letter dated the 18th of June last I beg to inform you that I have made an inspection of (St Philips) Keeseekoose Indian Boarding School near Kamsack Sask.

The main building 68 by 24 ft with extension 30 ft 20 ft one and onehalf stories in height contains the class room, boys play room, dining room and dormitories, is erected of logs there is also two additions of frame as will be seen from sketch one used for the kitchen the other for a chapel each one story in height, each 19 ft square.

The log portion of building is strapped and plastered on the outside as well as the inside making a fairly warm building.

The ceilings are very low in both stories providing very limited accommodation and the building is without conveniences of any kind and unless very considerable additions are added so as to increase the accommodation it is unnecessary to provide them.

The class room is 28'4" x 19'4" and provides a usable area for 15 pupils. The dormitories each for boys and girls 18'6" x 23' x 9' in height and provide air space for 7 1/2 pupils each.

The church authorities interested are anxious to extend the building and I have been informed that it is their intention to approach the Department with the view of increasing the maximum number of pupils providing that satisfactory buildings are erected.

I have prepared sketch draft for this purpose designed to accommodate 40 pupils utilizing the present building. The new portion of the building to be erected in such a way that future additions may be added from levels.
that future additions may be added from time to time thus completing the new building and removing the old portion and these using for other purposes.

The site of the building is good and provides adequate facilities for water, light and drainage.

The School has a farm of 160 acres about 80 acres being under cultivation, the grain and root crops all being in excellent condition.

With respect to the additions which it is intended to erect providing satisfactory arrangements are made with the Department it is not expected that they will enable the School to qualify as in Class A, but the work will all be done in such a way that when the whole of the building is re-built that it will so classify.

Sir,

I beg to inform the Department that I visited the St Phillips School on the 4th inst on which day the School re-opened after the winter vacation.

Rev Father Poulet, the principal, informed me that when he was authorised to provide the pupils with a mid-day meal no provision was made for the supplying of the necessary table utensiles needed in serving the meal, and requested me to take the matter up with the Department with a view of having them supplied. The articles most necessary are, 1-10gal Tea Pot, 2 doz each, Knives, Forks, Spoons, 1 Soup Ladle and Oil-Cloth for Dining-Room Table, and I beg to recommend that they be supplied. These articles could be purchased locally, if the Department so wish, at an expenditure of about $20.00.

The Rev Father Poulet drew my attention to several improvements in the class-room he had made at an expenditure of about $250.00 during the vacation, which are of material benefit to the comfort and convenience of the pupils and staff. The most important improvement consists of the removing of the partition, thereby making two rooms into one and increasing the size of the class-room, laying a new floor, and providing a vestibule cloak-room at the children's entrance, and re-painting the class-room.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, March 19, 1925.

Dear Father Boys:

I have to inform you that Parliament has been asked to make an appropriation for a small residential building, to be known as the Keesakeeese Indian Boarding School. I am of the opinion that the needs will be met if accommodation for 50 pupils is provided. I would be pleased to have any suggestions from you as to the type of building that is desired. I will then arrange for rough sketches, which will be submitted to you for your consideration. When any changes or ideas of yours have been embodied in these sketches, proper plans will be prepared by the Department.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. F. D. Boys, O.M.I.,
223 Provencher Ave.,
St. Boniface, Man.
Honourable Sir:

I am in receipt of Your letter of the 19th inst.(117-3-5), and thank You heartily for the good news imparted to me of the intention of the Department to build a residential school in Keeseekoose reserve.

I take the liberty to send You a plan and some specifications, which contain the substance of our views in the matter.

May I suggest that we be given charge to supervise the work of construction of said school. This method has fully succeeded in Fort Alexander. It is vital for our work to secure good substantial building.

I and all our Principals gratefully appreciate Your sympathetic activities in behalf of our Indian Schools.

Yours very Sincerely,

Dear Sir:

The plan of Mr. Intesh shall prove very satisfactory for the Nejekknee School.

The only suggestions we would make would be to have the girls' recreation and closets about where the two small dining rooms are located. This would not probably require an extra expense and has been executed in Mr. Intesh's plan.

A root cellar however and a soft water tank should be provided as well as a septic tank. The root cellar is placed in Mr. Intesh's plan. The soft water tank is an absolute necessity in that country of hard water and therefore rain water should be stored carefully, both for furnace and laundry.

We would greatly prefer not to have columns in the class room if this could be attained without too much extra expense.

Thanking You for Your kind attention in sending me the plans, I remain,

WATER SOFTENER
Is One of Nature's Greatest Blessings

Most of us doubtless recall our old home, or that of our grandparents, where the old rain barrel stood at the corner of the house. In summer it supplied the water for the weekly washing, and there was enough generally for the washbowl and pitcher in the "spare room". That was known as soft water. Being Heaven sent we felt that it was distilled by the gods and of course pure. We can also remember the old cistern wherein the rain water from the roof was stored in the ground and there allowed to remain as a source of supply when we could not catch it from the roof itself.

Of course we thought that rain water was pure because it was soft water. Soft water means the elimination of lime and magnesium, but the elimination of these two hardening factors does not purify the water. Few of us would drink the rain water from the roof.

The provisions of Nature are bountiful, but the rains which refresh the earth have another mission—to clarify and purify the atmosphere. This means that the rain water in the cistern or in the old rain barrel carried dust and grime from roofs and trees.

Today for household use soft water is furnished from few public and private supplies. That which comes through the tap into our kitchens from the city or town main, is hard—often extremely hard. Is there, then, you may wonder, no method by which water can be softened and made available for all household necessities and yet remain pure enough to drink.

Yes—REFFINITE Softens Water Perfectly

Nature has blessed mankind again and given us a mineral which is called "Refinite". It is a natural water softening mineral, a product from Nature's own laboratory. It is dug from the earth itself, and placed in a container, and the hard water full of lime and magnesium passing through the container and over the mineral is softened.

REFFINITE Soft Water Better Than Rain Water

Not only is Refinite soft water softer than rain itself for every drop of water contains some small portion of the hardening salts, whereas Refinite soft water is 100 per cent soft, for all of the hardening elements are taken out of the water. Then too, Refinite Soft Water is absolutely pure—as pure as the water before it is sent through the softener. Therefore it is not only suitable for drinking purposes because it is pure, but it is better for drinking because it is soft.

How Refinite Softens Water

Refinite is a flinty, porous mineral and insoluble in water. In its original state it is classified as a natural zeolite. We process and prepare it for use in the Refinite Water Softener at our factory near the mineral fields. Refinite is our registered name for the finished product.

When Refinite has softened its rated capacity of water, it must be regenerated. This does not mean that it is to be removed from the Softener or replaced by new mineral. Its softening properties are restored by simply allowing a brine solution (common salt water) to stand in the container 45 minutes. The brine is flushed out through the drain and the mineral is again ready for its next run.

In the home or domestic Softener, regeneration is necessary usually about once a month. This depends, however, upon the capacity of the Softener installed and the degree of hardness of the water to be softened.

The Industrial Type REFINITE SOFTENER shown consists of a steel tank welded or riveted with man-hole and inlet and outlet connections for the hard and soft water lines. GENERAL DESCRIPTION

Standard Pressure Filters are built for 67 pounds working pressure per square inch and tested to 100 pounds. The filtering materials are specially selected and graded silica sand and gravel.

Valves and fittings 3 inches and smaller are screwed pattern, 4 inch and larger are flanged.

The water enters the filter at the top and is deflected by a baffle plate so that the filter bed is not disturbed. It then passes downward uniformly through the filter bed and is collected in a piping system covering the entire bottom of the filter, and passes to the outlet.

The suspended matter which it is desired to filter from the water collects on the upper portion of the filter bed and when sufficient has collected to cause a loss in pressure of 5 pounds the filter must be cleaned, which is accomplished by reversing the flow of water and washing upward through the filter and out at the top to the waste.

The use of a Coagulant is essential with a Pressure Sand Filter if it is desired to remove all suspended matter visible to the naked eye. This Coagulant usually Ammonium Aluminum Sulfate, commonly called Filter Alum, is introduced to the water by means of the Pressure Coagulant Feeder which consists of an iron container with the necessary valves, pipes and fittings to allow a small portion of the water going to the filter to be by-passed through it and return back to the inlet line of the filter carrying a small amount of Alum in solution. When the water contains sufficient alkalinity, this minute amount of Alum produces Hydrate of Alumina, a sticky gelatinous substance which brings the impurities in the water together into large particles and thus is unable to pass the top of the filter bed.

In the case of swimming pools or natural water supplies having very little alkalinity, an additional Pressure Chemical Feeder, similar to the Alum Feeder should be used to introduce small amounts of Soda Ash, or some such chemical, to the water.

It is important that the filter be back-washed when necessary and that sufficient water be available for this purpose. Care should be taken by the operator, when back-washing, that he does not exceed the rate of 15 gallons per square foot per minute and thus wash sand out to the sewer and possibly disturb the filter bed, also that he does not waste water by endeavoring to wash at too slow a rate.

Sir,

In checking up the drainage from the building to the septic tank with the contractor, it was pointed out to him that the separate pipe from the kitchen sinks and laundry tubs was not to go thru the septic tank but to be carried to the manhole direct from the building, and all disposal from the manhole was to be carried in one pipe to the disposal field.

He informed me that he figured on taking the sanitary and laundry drain pipes under the basement floor to the outside of the building then connect the two pipes into the 8" sewer pipe going to the septic tank. When he figured on the work he did not find any mention in the plans and specifications of taking the separate pipe to the manhole as outlined to him by me.

In checking up the plans and specifications I find that the plans calls for one 6" pipe connection to the septic tank and one 6" outlet from the syphon chamber.

I would refer you to page 51 paragraph 6 wherein it says that the drainage from the kitchen sinks and laundry tubs shall be carried separately outside the building.

I would also refer you to page 76 of the specifications dealing with the location of septic tank and sewer line, it says that the sewer pipe from the building to the septic tank to be 8" in diameter vitrified clay pipe, the discharge pipe from the septic tank to the field tiles shall be of similar pipe 6" in diameter.

Personally I understood that the laundry pipe should not go into the tank but go direct to the manhole. The contractor must have got confused with the plans and specifications not agreeing as to the size of the pipe going to the tank from the building and the discharge pipe from syphon chamber. Also no mention been made of a bye pass on the laundry pipe to the first manhole on the west side of the tank.

Kindly advise me as soon as you can on your finding on the interpretation of the plans and specifications by the contractor.

Your Obedient Servant,

Rodrick Grant

The well is down to a depth of 36ft x 3'8" in dia., the well is circular and cribbed to a depth of 26ft with lumber and the lower portion with brick. The well was put down last year.

There is approx. 3ft of water in the well and quicksand was reached at the present depth when the well was put down. I understand that they could not go further as they had no pumps. The supply of water is abundant for ordinary domestic use as the well stands at present.

Handpump we were able to pump 4 barrels before it showed any signs of empty and after an interval of 10 minutes the water supply renewed again. The pipe does not go down more than 2ft in the water below the normal water level.

We are not in a position to give a definite report on the capacity of this well without a suitable pump and sandpoint to make a test.

It is possible that if this well was put down 10ft lower there might be an abundant supply of water for all requirements.

This well is located too near the front of the building and some distance from the machinery room.

I would recommend that we put down a test hole for water on the left side elevation near the machinery room and if successful dig a well deep enough to ensure a sufficient supply of water 6ft in dia. There is no doubt in my mind but that water of a sufficient quantity required for domestic use and fire protection will be found on either site providing it was put down deeper in the quicksand than the present well.

Sir,

Answering your letter of Sept. 30th with reference to the prices quoted by the contractor to haul earth to grade where required around the building and the sewer lines, the contractor price was based upon the difficulty of getting teams and men owing to the threshing operations.

I have taken the matter up with him and he agrees to do the work for $1.50 per yard and have the earth placed where directed and graded to the stakes.

Where the sewers lines come out of the building they are down 4' below basement floor outside the building they are 6' below natural grade to top of pipe. Where the pipe enters the septic tank it is down 2' from grade to top of pipe. Where the two 6" pipes enter No. 1 manhole on west side of septic tank, they are down 2' 6" to the top of the pipes.

At the entrance to the inspection chamber 200 ft. from the building the pipe is down 2' 4" below grade.

The 4" Terra Cotta field tiles are down approximately 8' below the surface, this was kept down to the sand and gravel formation for the absorption field, the more absorbent the soil, the less danger there is of the field freezing; for protection from frost, it is considered well to have the field tiles covered with 12" of straw during our winters here. The only additions at present is to cover the sewage pipe lines with earth from the building to the inspection chambers. The manholes have been kept high enough to have 9' of earth above the sewer pipes.

It will not be necessary to haul earth to cover the septic tank as the excavation taken out will be sufficient.

The top of the manholes on top of septic tank are the same level as the other two manholes on the sewer lines.

I may say that in the contractor's first estimate he figured on ploughing 24" at the front near the ditch at the roadway, which is the high point of the elevations.

We will not do anything to this just grade sufficiently to drain the water from the building, this can be done another time.

With reference to Indian labour, at present they are preparing for threshing; I had a figure from some of them, they would agree to haul earth at $1.25 per yard after threshing but no levelling up to be done.

Personally I would not like to have anything to do with them on this work as they are not to be depended on; they might work for a day or two then not show up and they like to cut their money every few days. They have no tools to do the work and we had quite an experience with them on this work already.
With reference to the contractor, I would like to say that up to the present time he has given a creditable job. There is a lot of work to be done yet on his contract and I do not think advisable to have another contractor do this work while he is here.

The earth will have to be hauled 300 yards to the farthest point of the grade.

It will take 180 C.Y. of earth to protect the sewer lines and approximately 320 C.Y. for grading around the left and right side elevations and rear elevation at the rear part of the building.

I have figured this out as economically as possible by providing for grading to be done to protect the building only. It would take thousands of yards of earth to grade to the height of the front of the main building.

I trust this information will be satisfactory.

I will supply the Department with a plan of the sewerage as installed.

Upon receipt of Department letter 117-3-15 of the 21st ultimo, asking me to make a recommendation as to the type of electric lighting plant which I would recommend for installation at the St. Philips School, I interviewed the representative of the Delco Light Company here and found that the question of water supply was involved. I therefore telegraphed the Secretary, asking what provision had been made for a well, and received a reply stating that no definite arrangements had been entered into and asking for a recommendation.

I got into communication with the Indian Agent at Emoack by telephone, and told him to procure a price from Mr. Waterman, who, earlier in the year, had tested and submitted a report on the old well. I have today received a letter from him stating that he doubts whether Mr. Waterman could undertake the work, and adds that Mr. Grant has been in communication direct with the Department at Ottawa and made certain recommendations, in view of which latter fact, Mr. McKenzie suggests waiting until Mr. Grant has received word from Ottawa. This is very confusing. Mr. Grant expects to receive some definite word from Ottawa, and I, also, have been requested to attend to the matter and make a recommendation. I think it would have been a more satisfactory procedure if Inspector Grant had referred his suggestions through this office. In view of the Department's letter to me of the 13th of April, last, I was not aware that he was submitting any recommendation to the Department, nor, apparently, was the Agent.

This matter should be settled at once, and I shall be glad if you will advise me whether it

Progress Report,

Sir:

I have the honour to submit my report on the work done by the contractors The Wyndals Construction Co., Ltd., on the erection of the St. Phillips School from Oct. 1st, to Oct. 20th.

The installation of the plumbing work is now well under way; all the roughing in work for the fixtures is done with all vent stacks carried thru to the roof; work is now under way on the main water lines and supply pipes to all the plumbing fixtures also the standpipes for fire protection.

The heating contractor is getting along well with his work on the heating installation; the boiler is placed on the foundation and equipped with all the necessary fittings and breeching to the chimney; all the steam mains and returns are installed in the basement and work is been done on the risers to the floors above with the necessary connections made for the radiators on each floor.

I expect we will have the heating plant in operation in about three weeks time.

The painting work has now been completed on the outside of the building.

The plastering work is going ahead; the first coat work is finished on the ground, first, and second floors; the putty coat finish is done on the second floor with the keene cement finish on the walls of the toilets and bathrooms as per the specifications.

All the carpenter work is done in the basement and the lathing is now being done and will be completed in a few days. The stern sash is now in place; the carpenters are fitting the inside sash.
The soft water tank is built under the floor of the laundry room as per your instructions; all concrete floors are finished in the basement except for the laundry, machinery, room floors, the verandas on the ground and first floors are framed for screens as per your instructions.

The tile drains for the disposal field is not complete yet as the contractor had to take his men away from this job to finish the floors in the basement and will resume work on this when he gets thru, there is about 100 lineal feet of tile to be laid.

The work is going ahead slowly but well, and I expect the finishing to be started as soon as the plaster work is fit to receive the trim on the second floor.

Your obedient Servant,

Sir:

I have the honour to report on the work done by the contractors The Wyndels Construction Co., Ltd., on the erection of the St. Phillips School, from Oct. 20th to Nov. 12th.

The contractor has completed all the outside work required to be done on the general contract including the erection of the fire escapes. The plumbing work on the installation of the fixtures will be completed in about a week's time, the standpipe system for fire protection is installed with hose racks and fire hose supplied, the hot water storage tank is set up on the pipe frame in the boiler room with all water and steam connections made, also the jacket heater for summer use.

The testing out of all water piping and fixtures can not be done until the water supply is connected to the system. The work on the heating installation is completed except for the connecting up of some 10 radiators in the basement, the boiler was fired up on the 27th of October to give heat in the basement and ground floor, the heat is now turned on throughout the building and drying out slowly; the work of covering the boiler and steam pipes will be started as soon as the test is complete.

The metal ceiling is complete on all floors except part of the basement which is underway. The plaster work is finished throughout the building.

All the concrete floors are now finished except for portions of the machinery room floor which was left off until the water supply was taken into the building. The carpenters are working on the finishing on the 2nd and 3rd floors. The painters are working on the metal ceiling, all the finishing trim is receiving a coat of stain before being put up.

The hardwood floors are laid on the 2nd, 3rd, and ground floors except the corridor of the ground floor, the work is going ahead with good results on all branches of the work.
The well is down two feet below the water level, the work on further excavations had to stop owing to the pumping arrangements not being suitable to keep the water low enough to permit going the required depth, a suitable pump is now on the way and we expect to have it here in a few days when work will be started again, the work is started on the foundations for the lean-to extension to the machinery room to house the pressure tank.

The contractor has advised me that the laundry machinery has been shipped, all the millwork is on the job except the stairs which has not arrived yet but I understand it is now shipped and should be here any time.

The contractor has contracted for enough fuel to heat the building until he is finished.

REGINA, SASK., Nov. 10th, 1927.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I wired you yesterday as follows,-

"Principal St. Philips School asks for root house size fourteen by twenty - Too late in season to pour concrete - Advise making excavation for root house size mentioned with temporary roof of straw and poles and using it for storage of this year's vegetables - Cost Eighty-five dollars. Kindly instruct."

A root house is no doubt needed at this point and I understand that to build a permanent cellar of the above dimensions with concrete walls 10" thick, roof slab 6" thick well reinforced, two reinforced concrete floor beams, concrete stairs, double doors and the necessary ventilators, roof slab covered over with roofing paper and earth would cost about $85.00.

The question of building a stable has also been brought up. We cannot build a stable at this late date, and I think the school authorities will have to carry on as they have in the past until the Spring. It will take $3800.00 to build a proper stable, and no doubt a henhouse and other buildings will be required, so that I think an appropriation of $5000.00 should be made to meet the cost of outside buildings for this institution.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

Your letter of the 5th instant in reply to my letter of the 3rd dealing with the fire escapes to hand, I would say that when I had asked for these openings to be framed for the fire doors to open outwards I was complying with the regulations governing exits to fire escapes, although the plans showed them to open inside. With regard to my proposal to have an additional door placed on the inside of the girls infirmary and the staff room above in the girls dormitory, I would recommend that we place metal weather stripping on the frame of the opening in the staff bedroom 2nd floor; it is not practical to open the fire door and the inside door outwards hinged on the same jamb.

About the door in the girls infirmary on the first floor I would not consider this a public exit to the fire escape as it opens from a private room which is to be used as a room for the sick, at most there would not be more than two patients occupying the room at the same time. If there was more beds placed in this room along with the rest of the furniture you would hardly expect to have a clear passageway to the fire escape if this particular fire escape opening was to be used first for the occupants of the room. I see no reason why an inside door should not be put on, unless you consider this a public exit, then it would not be practical to have an inside door opening inwards, on this particular floor we have a class room which is near the fire escape at the other end and all occupants on that side of the stairs would take it, on the side with the girls infirmary the occupants will be the sisters, except during part of the day there may be girls in the sewing room or cleaning up on the daily dusting, the principle agrees with me that the exit is only a semi-public one. If you are still opposed to the placing of this door on the inside we will place the metal weather stripping on the frame same as the opening above, the principle would like to have a door on during the cold months, I may say that we placed a transom over this door to be opened, as there was only one window in this room so that there would be a circulation of air without opening the fire door.

With regard to my suggestion to have ladder from the roof of the porch at the girl's end the matter was first taken up with the principle who wanted it operated from the window in the vestry on the ground floor. The ladder would be in a horizontal position when not in use, and in the event of fire it would be operated from the window, the principle says that he would not have a portable one kept inside the building for use in the event of fire, the height of the roof of the porch from the ground is 10 feet, and there would be the possibility of a jam on this roof as the area is only 42 sq feet. We have also to remember that its possible in the event of fire to have to carry out the patients from the infirmary.

Your obedient servant,

Sdg. Roderick Grant.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have had some correspondence with Mr. Grant, the Inspector of Construction, at the new St. Philips School in regard to the fire escapes and exits thereto. After receiving your letter of the 25th ultimo I gave instructions that the exit doors should be made to open outwards and these directions are being carried out.

I would point out, however, that on the girl's side of the school the exit to the fire escape on the second floor is through a staff bedroom, and that from the first floor through the girl's infirmary. At both these exits Mr. Grant suggested that an inner door should be hung opening inwards to make the rooms more weather proof during the winter. I wrote stating that the object of placing the exit doors to open outwards could be defeated if another door were to be placed at the same exit opening inwards, and I enclose a copy of his reply.

I am of the opinion that it would be a dangerous precedent to allow the placing of a door to open inwards at fire exits, and while Mr. Grant suggests that the exit at the other end of the passage on the boy's side could be used as the public exit, this will only apply on the first floor as there is no means of communication on the 2nd floor. The only alternative would be to put metal weather stripping on the frames of the doors referred to, and after all this is really only a makeshift.

Another point taken up with me by Mr. Grant was that the fire escape on the girl's side ended on the roof of the porch below from which there is a drop of 10 feet to the ground. His suggestion was to have a ladder from the porch roof, and I pointed out that this was undesirable as it would afford ingress to the building to mischievous boys. The last paragraph in his letter suggests that this, when not in use, will be in a horizontal position and could be operated from the vestry on the ground floor, and this arrangement, of course, presupposes that some one would always be available in the vestry to let down the ladder. I do not like any of Mr. Grant's proposals to correct the original defects in planning the fire escapes, and I should like to have an expression of opinion from you.

Yours truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,

I have the honour to submit my report on the work done by the contractors The Wyndels Construction Co., Ltd., on the erection of the St. Phillips School from Nov. 12th to Dec. 6th.

The heating contractor has completed his work on the heating installation, including the covering of the boiler and the steam mains in the basement; we have made arrangements that he will have the boilers cleaned when we have the water pressure in the water system completed; he has to install a heating coil in the pump house; we are now building; it is our intention to use soft water in the boiler when the boilers are cleaned as we have approximately 250 gals in the tank.

The plumbing contract is now completed except for the installation of the sink in the scullery; this will be done when the plumbers come back to test out the water pipes and fixtures when the water system is connected up. The carpenter work on the finishing is 90% finished except for the building of the stairs; work was started on the stairs today.

The painting work inside the building is well advanced with the barring on the walls in the corridors except for the staircase. I estimate that the painting work is 80% finished.

The electrical contract will be finished about the 13th instant when all the fixtures will be installed.

We have installed a Delec light generating unit 110 volts, 1000 watts capacity.

The laundry machinery is set in place with hot and cold water connections made to the machines; also the necessary drain connection to the sewer.

I would report that we have the well finished to the required depth, having a water reservoir of 8' deep with a flow of approximately 600 gals per hour.

The contractor is building the pump house over the well to house the pressure tank and I expect the work to be far enough advanced this week to allow the plumbers make the installation for the water supply.

All the metal ceilings throughout the building is covered with the painting complete.

I may say that it is not decided yet whether power is to be used to run the laundry machinery; the contractor cannot complete the installation until the decision is made.

Sir:—

I received your letter of the 19th November with reference to the power to be used to operate the laundry machinery. I would recommend that these machines be electrically driven from an economical standpoint as well as being the most convenient to suit the space available. The Principal is very anxious to have it run this way as it will be easier for the Sisters to operate when starting up than it would be with a gasoline engine. They could not start the engine up themselves and there would not be a man there all the time. We could install another unit of the Delco plant now installed, which would make the electrical capacity 3 H.P., enough to run the laundry machines, pump and dough mixer, if it is your intention to have one installed. I would recommend that you install another unit of the Delco plant of the following type, 110 volts, D.C. 1250 watts. The batteries now installed will be sufficient for the additional unit.

If you install a gasoline engine it will require one of the capacity of 6 H.P. This will take up more room with the cooling; it will also use up more gasoline and it is not very convenient to drive the dough mixer, as the belts would be run through the corridor. If you install mixer it will be of one sack capacity and it would take 1½ h.p. The laundry machines would not be run at the same time as the mixer. The mixer should have a meter attached.

You will have to supply a gasoline storage tank of 300 gals. capacity for either an extra unit or engine if used. It would take 1½ H.P. motor to run the laundry machinery. Again, if we put in a gasoline engine we will have to use a counter shaft on the laundry machines as we have to place the machines close to the south wall to give all the room possible in the laundry room. I may say that the radiators are placed on the ceiling in this room which makes it necessary to use a counter shaft to run off the line shaft.

Dear Mr. Scott:

The question of power to operate the laundry machinery which it is proposed to install in the new St. Phillip's Indian Residential School on the Keeseekoose reserve is now being brought to my attention. I understand that the machinery is being supplied by the contractor, but the question of power to operate it has not been settled.

In discussing this matter with Mr. Sharpe, who is supplying the lighting plant, he states that to expect the existing plant to operate this heavy standard laundry machinery would be out of the question, but suggests that another unit be added to the lighting plant, which would operate with the same set of batteries. By adding this unit it would do away with the using of the batteries for the operation of the laundry equipment, as it would be operated from the two generating units.

This means of supplying power is the only one that is practicable, especially in an institution where there are only women to operate the laundry machinery, and besides, we have not the space in which to install a gasoline engine.

I should be glad to have your authority to install an additional unit to the plant already on the ground, at a cost of $613.00, fob. Kamloops, installed. It will also be necessary to install a 1½ H.P. motor for this unit, at an approximate cost of $120.00.

I enclose herewith a copy of Mr. Roderick Grant's letter on the subject, which may be of interest.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Graham,

Replying to your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to the power for the laundry machinery at the new St. Phillips School, I would ask you to arrange for the installation of a 6 H.P. gasoline engine to operate the laundry machinery. This engine should be installed in the machinery room, as shown on the plan and connected to a line shaft passing through the wall and belted to the laundry machinery.

For your information I would point out that the two water generators as suggested by you would have a capacity of 250 lbs., which is equal to 250/3 H.P., making the generators at 80% efficiency, which is the highest rating you can give to a generator. As it requires 50 H.P. to operate the laundry machinery, you will see that the generating plant falls considerably short of generating sufficient power. I would also point out that it requires considerably more than 50 H.P. to start the laundry machinery, as it has been found by experience that when the washer and wringer are filled with clothes it takes at least 5 H.P. to get them under way. The contractors completed the work on their contract on the 30th of Dec., except for the supplying of the necessary shafting and pulleys required to run the laundry machinery, we received definite instructions from Mr. Graham on the 27th Dec., that the department wanted the laundry machinery run by a gasoline engine, the contractor has arranged to have this shipment made and installation completed as per the specifications dealing with laundry machinery.

The contractor kept the building heated during the months of November and December, and as their contract was completed, except for the completion of the laundry installation, and as they were not responsible for this delay we could not ask them to continue to keep the building heated any longer, I asked the principle to supply fuel.

The heating contractor installed heating coil in the pumphouse, and completed his contract when he had the boiler cleaned as per the specifications.

The plumbing contract was completed with the installation of the scullery sink, the water system is now installed and connected to the 2nd supply main, all water pipes and fixtures has been tested out and any leaks that showed were made good.

The electrical contract is completed with all the fixtures installed as per the specifications.

The pumphouse is complete, with the pressure tank in place and connected up to the pump and the house supply pipe.

The standpipe system was tested out and worked satisfactory, the nozzle will send a stream of water 40ft from the end of the hose on the second floor.

All the carpenter work was finished including the placing of the window shades on all windows.

All the painting and varnishing was completed as per the specifications, including the burlap on the walls in the corridors and stairways.

As soon as the gasoline engine will arrive it will be installed in the machinery room, since the contractor finished heating the building I have attended to the firing of the boiler.

Your Obedient Servant,

Inspector of Construction.

The Secretary

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to the placing of a door between the boys' and girls' dormitories in the new St. Phillips School, I beg to say that before the plans for the building were completed a copy was sent to the Reverend Father Pope, then Provincial at St. Joseph's, and they were approved by him. Sir;

Re- Extra work on pumphouse.

The estimate to build the pumphouse did not include the laying of a concrete floor nor the drainage from the floor. The excavations for the pit to place the pump was done when the ground was frozen, this work was not started until the well was finished as the well is located inside the pumphouse. The floor of the pumphouse is down lower than the floor of the machinery room 4' and the floor of the pit for the pump is down 4' lower than the pumphouse floor. We had to go down with the base for the pump so that the suction lift would not be more than 21' 6".

We put a floor drain in the pumphouse and connected same to the boiler room drain. The drain is required in this floor as it will be necessary to clean out the pressure tank when it becomes water logged.

This work was done during very cold weather. It was not until the 29th of Nov. that the well was finished when a start was made on the building of the pumphouse, all the gravel had to be heated for the concrete.

Sir,

Extras on pumphouse

We had to put an extra ply of V joint and two ply of tar paper on the inside walls of the pumphouse above the concrete walls. This had to be done to protect the water system from freezing up as all the concrete work was done in very cold weather and the ground was frozen at the time we worked on the concrete. It was hard to heat the building to keep it above freezing point. The connections for the heating is taken off the end of the 2" main in the machinery room so fire had to be maintained in the boilers to keep the pumphouse above freezing point. It meant that more fuel was burnt to help out the pumphouse, the connections being made at the end of the steam main made it more difficult to heat the room while everything was cold. This is been overcome now as the frost is out of the walls.

We also put 3 ply of tar paper under the rubberoid roofing.

The electrical for the pumphouse was not included in the estimate.

As instructed by your official letter dated the 12th of June last I beg to inform you that I have made an inspection of (St Philips) Keesekoose Indian Boarding School near Kamsack Sask.

The main building 62 by 24 ft with extension 20 ft 30 ft one and onehalf stories in height contains the classroom, boys play room, dining room and dormitories, is erected of logs there is also two additions of frame as will be seen from sketch one used for the kitchen the other for a chapel each one story in height, each 19 ft square.

The log portion of building is strapped and plastered on the outside as well as the inside making a fairly warm building.

The ceilings are very low in both stories providing a very limited accommodation and the building is without conveniences of any kind and unless very considerable addition are added so as to increase the accommodation it is unnecessary to provide them.

The class room is 22'4"x 18'4" and provides a cubic area for 15 pupils. The dormitories each for boys and girls 18'6"x 23' x 9' in height and provide air space for 7 1/2 pupils each.

The church authorities interested are anxious to extend the building and I have been informed that it is their intention to approach the department with the view of increasing the number of pupils providing that satisfactory buildings are erected.

I have prepared sketch draft for this purpose designed to accommodate 40 pupils utilizing the present building. The new portion of the building to be erected in such a way that future additions may be added from time to time.
that future additions may be added from time to time thus completing the new building and removing the old portion and these using for other purposes.

The site of the building is good and provides adequate facilities for water, light and drainage.

The School has a farm of 160 acres about 80 acres being under cultivation, the grain and root crops all being in excellent condition.

With respect to the additions which it is intended to erect providing satisfactory arrangements are made with the Department it is not expected that they will enable the School to qualify as in Class A, but the work will all be done in such a way that when the whole of the building is re-built that it will so classify.

Original on 184487-6

There is a matter which I wish to bring to your attention. There is great need for a recreation room, especially in the winter time. As it is they have to play in the class-room in winter and when the weather is wet in summer. In addition to this they use the class-room every school day to eat their lunch and the result is the desks and floor become smeared up with grease. I understand from the principal that he has a room near the class-room that could be relined and fixed up at a cost of $100.00, and which would make a good playroom. If it would be in order to spend Government money on this building, I would strongly advise that it be done as we have a good school at this point costing very little money.

(Sgd.) W. M. Graham,
Inspector.

Sir,

Halter and Co., for supplies for mid-day meal at St. Phillip's School, Keesekoonse, I beg to inform the Department that these supplies have been purchased at various times since receipt of Department's letter No. 184487-5 of June 28th.

Sir,

I beg to inform the Department that I visited the St Phillips School on the 4th inst on which day the School re-opened after the winter vacation.

Rev Father Poulet, the principal, informed me that when he was authorised to provide the pupils with a mid-day meal no provision was made for the supplying of the necessary table utensiles needed in serving the meal, and requested me to take the matter up with the Department with a view of having them supplied. The articles most necessary are, 1-1 Gal Tea Pot, 2 doz each, Knives, Forks, Spoons, 1 Soup Ladle and Oil-Cloth for Dining-Room Table, and I beg to recommend that they be supplied. These articles could be purchased locally, if the Department so wish, at an expenditure of about $20.00.

The Rev Father Poulet drew my attention to several improvements in the class-room he had made at an expenditure of about $250.00 during the vacation, which are of material benefit to the comfort and convenience of the pupils and staff. The most important improvement consists of the removing of the partition, thereby making two rooms into one and increasing the size of the class-room, laying a new floor, and providing a vestibule cloak-room at the children's entrance, and re-painting the class-room.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

Acting Indian Agent

Ottawa, March 19, 1923.

Dear Father Beys:

I have to inform you that Parliament has been asked to make an appropriation for a small residential building, to be known as the Keeseekoose Indian Boarding School. I am of the opinion that the needs will be met if accommodation for 50 pupils is provided. I would be pleased to have any suggestions from you as to the type of building that is desired. I will then arrange for rough sketches, which will be submitted to you for your consideration. When any changes or ideas of yours have been embodied in these sketches, proper plans will be prepared by the Department.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. F. B. Beys, O.M.I.,
222 Provencher Ave.,
St. Boniface, Man.
Honourable Sir:

I am in receipt of Your letter of the 19th inst. (117-3-5), and thank You heartily for the good news imparted to me of the intention of the Department to build a residential school in Keesekouse reserve.

I take the liberty to send You a plan and some specifications, which contain the substance of our views in the matter.

May I suggest that we be given charge to supervise the work of construction of said school. This method has fully succeeded in Fort Alexander. It is vital for our work to secure good substantial building.

I and all our Principals gratefully appreciate Your sympathetic activities in behalf of our Indian Schools.

Yours very Sincerely,

[Signature]

In my requests in view of the estimates for the construction of a Residential School at St. Philippe's, acting upon the suggestion of Very Reverend Father Beys and Mr. Graham, I had indicated that a construction for 100 children be erected.

Dear Sir:

The plan of Mc Intosh shall prove very satisfactory for the Keejokkoos School.

The only suggestions we would make would be to have the girls recreation and closets about where the two small dining rooms are located. This would not probably require an extra expense and has been executed in Mc Intosh.

A root cellar however and a soft water tank should be provided as well as a septic tank. The root cellar is placed in Mc Intosh as stated in the plan. The soft water tank is an absolute necessity in that country of hard water and therefore rain water should be stored carefully, both for furnace and laundry.

We would greatly prefer not to have columns in the class room if this could be attained without too much extra expense.

Thanking You for Your kind attention in sending me the plans, I remain

"This school is held in a large two storied building
