GENERAL DESCRIPTION

Standard Pressure Filters are built for 67 pounds working pressure per square inch and tested to 100 pounds. The filtering materials are specially selected and graded silica sand and gravel. Valves and fittings 3 inches and smaller are screwed pattern, 4 inch and larger are flanged.

The water enters the filter at the top and is deflected by a baffle plate so that the filter bed is not disturbed. It then passes downward uniformly through the filter bed and is collected in a piping system covering the entire bottom of the filter, and passes to the outlet.

The suspended matter which it is desired to filter from the water collects on the upper portion of the filter bed and when sufficient has collected to cause a loss in pressure of 5 pounds the filter must be cleaned, which is accomplished by reversing the flow of water and washing upward through the filter and out at the top to the waste.

The use of a Coagulant is essential with a Pressure Sand Filter if it is desired to remove all suspended matter visible to the naked eye. This Coagulant usually Ammonium Aluminium Sulphate, commonly called Filter Alum, is introduced to the water by means of the Pressure Coagulant Feeder which consists of an iron container with the necessary valves, pipes and fittings to allow a small portion of the water going to the filter to be by-passed through it and return back to the inlet line of the filter carrying a small amount of Alum in solution. When the water contains sufficient alkalinity, this minute amount of Alum produces Hydrate of Alumina, a sticky gelatinous substance which clings to the impurities in the water together into large particles and thus is unable to pass the bed of the filter bed.

In the case of swimming pools or natural water supplies having very little alkalinity, an additional Pressure Chemical Feeder, similar to the Alum Feeder should be used to introduce small amounts of Soda Ash, or some such chemical, to the water.

It is important that the filter be back-washed when necessary and that sufficient water be available for this purpose. Care should be taken by the operator, when back-washing, that he does not exceed the rate of 15 gallons per square foot per minute and thus wash sand out to the sewer and possibly disturb the filter bed, also that he does not waste water by endeavoring to wash at too slow a rate.

Industrial Type Water Softeners

Water Softeners using REFINITE have been in satisfactory use in the largest laundries, industries, hotels and institutions in Canada for years.

REFINITE RAPID REGENERATING MINERAL is the same material that has during the last ten years proven itself capable of delivering high softening rates and large capacities between regenerations without disintegrating and without discoloring the water.

The Industrial Type REFINITE SOFTENER shown consists of a steel tank welded or riveted with man-hole and inlet and outlet connections for the hard and soft water lines. The tank is ordinarily built to withstand a working pressure of 67 pounds per square inch, but can be built to meet any requirements.

The salt tank is of steel of sufficient size to hold the salt required for each regeneration.

All pipes, valves and fittings to connect the softener tank and the salt tank are furnished as shown. The purchaser only needs to connect his hard water line and softened water line and furnish sewer connections to complete his piping before commencing operation.

Where steam is available a steam ejector is used to circulate the water in the softener through the salt tank, dissolving the salt and as the brine passes through the REFINITE bed it completely removes the hardness forming salts that were taken from the water which has been softened.

In the lower part of the Softener tank an under drain and collector system of special bronze strainers connected to the inlet or hard water line allows the water when softening to pass uniformly UPWARDS through a shallow bed of specially selected silica gravel which acts as a further diffuser and causes the water to rise evenly through the REFINITE mineral which rests on the gravel and fills the balance of the space in the Softener tank to a point near the outlet at the top.

The gravel and REFINITE are shipped in bags ready for putting in the Softener tank.

A meter to measure the water softened is furnished and where required we furnish a special contact bell-ringing attachment which draws the operator's attention when the full capacity of the softener has been used and regeneration is necessary.

Regeneration consists of dissolving the salt in the brine tank and forcing it several times through the bed of REFINITE mineral by means of the steam ejector, or when steam is not available, circulating it with a bronze pump connected to a motor. Regeneration of the mineral is complete in thirty minutes.

The uses of Softened Water are many and varied. Laundries save one-third to more than one-half of their washroom supplies and turn out finished work which is impossible with unsoftened water. Textile mills save soap, soda, dyes and improve their products and the price they get for them. Power plants everywhere eliminate scale in their boilers and other hard water troubles. The benefits of eliminating the hardness forming salts from water in industries and institutions are now so well known that further comment is unnecessary.

Sir,

In checking up the drainage from the building to the septic tank with the contractor, it was pointed out to him that the separate pipe from the kitchen sinks and laundry tubs was not to go thru the septic tank but to be carried to the manhole direct from the building, and all disposal from the manhole was to be carried in one pipe to the disposal field.

He informed me that he figured on taking the sanitary and laundry drain pipes under the basement floor to the outside of the building then connect the two pipes into the 8" sewer pipe going to the septic tank. When he figured on the work he did not find any mention in the plans and specifications of taking the separate pipe to the manhole as outlined to him by me.

In checking up the plans and specifications I find that the plans calls for one 6" pipe connection to the septic tank and one 6" outlet from the syphon chamber.

I would refer you to page 51 paragraph 6 wherein it says that the drainage from the kitchen sinks and laundry tubs shall be carried separately outside the building.

I would also refer you to page 76 of the specifications dealing with the location of septic tank and sewer line, it says that the sewer pipe from the building to the septic tank to be 8" in diameter vitrified clay pipe, the discharge pipe from the septic tank to the field tiles shall be of similar pipe 8" in diameter.

Personally I understood that the laundry pipe should not go into the tank but go direct to the manhole. The contractor must have got confused with the plans and specifications not agreeing as to the size of the pipe going to the tank from the building and the discharge pipe from syphon chamber. Also no mention been made of a bye pass on the laundry pipe to the first manhole on the west side of the tank.

Kindly advise me as soon as you can on your finding on the interpretation of the plans and specifications by the contractor.

Sir,

Re- water supply.

With reference to your letter of July 26th, I beg to report that there is a well located near the building site of the St. Phillips School.

The well is located at the right side elevation and 21ft north of the building and 29ft back from the line of the front elevation.

The well is down to a depth of 38ft x 3'8" in dia., the well is circular and cribbed to a depth of 26ft with lumber and the lower portion with brick. The well was put down last year.

There is approx. 3ft of water in the well and quicksand was reached at the present depth. When the well was put down I understand that they could not go further as they had no pumps. The supply of water is abundant for ordinary domestic use as the well stands at present.

By using the present hand pump we were able to pump 4 barrels before it showed any signs of empty and after an interval of 10 minutes the water supply renewed again. The pipe does not go down more than 2ft in the water below the normal water level.

We are not in a position to give a definite report on the capacity of this well without a suitable pump and sandpoint to make a test.

This well was put down 10ft lower there might be an abundant supply of water for all requirements. This well is located too near the front of the building and some distance from the machinery room.

I would recommend that we put down a test hole for water on the left side elevation near the machinery room and if successful dig a well deep enough to ensure a sufficient supply of water 6ft in dia., there is no doubt in my mind but that water of a sufficient quantity required for domestic use and fire protection will be found on either site providing it was put down deeper in the quicksand than the present well.

I am your obedient servant.

Inspector Of Construction

Sir:

I have the honour to submit my report on the work done by the contractors on the erection of the St. Phillips School for the two weeks ending Oct. 1st.

Since my last report all the siding on the main building and the rear part has been completed with all cornice and outside trim finished, all lathing is finished on the ground, first, and second floors.

The plumbing work is now well advanced on the drainage under the basement floor all the sanitary sewer drains and the separate pipe taking the laundry, kitchen sinks drainage has been tested out as per the specifications.

The rainwater pipe has been installed with the necessary connections made to all the hoppers on the flat roofs.

The steamfitters has started on the work of installing the heating plant, the boiler is in place ready for the foundation all radiators has been placed on all the upper floors and work has been started on the pipe work by the heating contractor, the jacket heater and the hot water storage tank has been delivered on the job.

The painting work on the outside of the building will be completed in a few days providing the weather suitable.

The stern sash has been fitted and painted and will be put on as soon the painting is dry.

Preparations are now being made ready for the plasterers who are expected to start work on the 5th, Oct.

The brickwork on the chimney has been completed, work will be started on the concrete floors in the basement in a few days. The septic tank is now constructed with all the manholes built as per requirements of the plan and specifications.
II.

With reference to the contractor, I would like to say that up to the present time he has given a creditable job. There is a lot of work to be done yet on his contract and I do not think advisable to have another contractor do this work while he is here.

The earth will have to be hauled 300 yards to the farthest point of the grade.

It will take 180 C.Y. of earth to protect the sewer lines and approximately 320 C.Y. for grading around the left and right side elevations and rear elevation at the rear part of the building.

I have figured this out as economically as possible by providing for grading to be done to protect the building only.

It would take thousands of yards of earth to grade to the height of the front of the main building.

I trust this information will be satisfactory.

I will supply the Department with a plan of the sewerage as installed.

Your Obedient Servant

Sir;

answering to your letter of Sept. 30th with reference to the price quoted by the contractor to haul earth to grade where required around the building and the sewer lines, the contractor price was based upon the difficulty of getting teams and men owing to the threshing operations.

I have taken the matter up with him and he agrees to do the work for $1.60 per yard and have the earth placed where directed and graded to the stakes.

Where the sewer lines come out of the building they are down 7' below the basement floor, outside the building they are 4' below natural grade to top of pipe. Where the pipe enters the septic tank it is down 2' 6" from grade to top of pipe. Where the two 6" pipes enter No. 1 manhole on west side of septic tank, they are down 2' 8" to the top of the pipes.

At the entrance to the inspection chamber 200 ft. from the building the pipe is down 12' 4" below grade.

The 4" Terra Cotta field tiles are down approximately 3' below the surface, this was kept down to the sand and gravel formation for the absorption field; the more absorbent the soil, the less danger there is of the field freezing. For protection from frost, it is considered well to have the field tiles covered with 12" of straw during our winters here. What I want done at present is to cover the sewerage pipe lines with earth from the building to the inspection chamber. The manholes have been kept high enough to have 7' of earth above the sewer pipes.

It will not be necessary to haul earth to cover the septic tank as the excavation taken out will be sufficient.

The top of the manholes on top of septic tank are the same level as the other two manholes on the sewer lines. I may say that in the contractor's first estimate he figured on ploughing 24" at the front near the ditch at the roadway, which is the high point of the elevation.

We will not do anything to this; just grade sufficiently to drain the water from the building, this can be done another time.

With reference to Indian labour, at present they are preparing for threshing; I had a figure from some of them, they would agree to haul earth at $1.25 per yard after threshing, but no levelling up to be done.

Personally I would not like to have anything to do with them on this work as they are not to be depended on; they might work for a day or two, then not show up and they like to sub their money every few days. They have no tools to do the work and we had quite an experience with them on this work already.

I have today received a letter from him stating that he doubts whether Mr. Waterman could undertake the work, and adds that Mr. Grant has been in communication direct with the Department at Ottawa and made certain recommendations, in view of which latter fact, Mr. McKenzie suggests waiting until Mr. Grant has received word from Ottawa. I have the honour to report on the work done by the contractors The Wyndels Construction Co., Ltd., on the erection of the St. Phillips School, from Oct. 20th to Nov. 12th. The metal ceiling is complete on all floors except part of the basement which is underway. The plaster work is finished throughout the building. All the concrete floors are now finished except for portion of the machinery room floor which was left off until the water supply was taken into the building. Dear Mr. Scott:

A root house is no doubt needed at this point and I understand that to build a permanent cellar of the above dimensions with concrete walls 10" thick, roof slab 6" thick well reinforced, two reinforced concrete floor beams, concrete stairs, double doors and the necessary ventilators, roof slab covered over with roofing paper and earth would cost about $35.00.

The question of building a stable has also been brought up. We cannot build a stable at this late date, and I think the school authorities will have to carry on as they have in the past until the Spring. Sir,

Your letter of the 5th instant in reply to my letter of the 3rd dealing with the fire escapes to hand, I would say that when I had asked for these openings to be framed for the fire doors to open outwards I was complying with the regulations governing exits to fire escapes, although the plans showed them to open inside. With regard to my proposal to have an additional door placed on the inside of the girls infirmary and the staff room above in the girls dormitory, I would recommend that we place metal weather stripping on the frame of the opening in the staff bedroom 2nd floor, it is not practical to open the fire door and the inside door outwards hinged on the same jamb.

About the door in the girls infirmary on the first floor I would not consider this a public exit to the fire escape as it opens from a private room which is to be used as a room for the sick, at most there would not be more than two patients occupying the room at the same time, if there was more beds placed in this room along with the rest of the furniture you would hardly expect to have a clear passageway to the fire escape if this particular fire escape opening was to be used first for the occupants of the room I see no reason why an inside door should not be put on, unless you consider this a public exit, then it would not be practical to have an inside door opening inwards, on this particular floor we have a class room which is near the fire escape at the other end and all occupants on that side of the stairs would take it, or the side with the girls infirmary the occupants will be the sisters, except during part of the day there may be girls in the sewing room or cleaning up on the daily dusting, the principle agrees with me that the exit is only a semi-public one, if you are still opposed to the placing of this door on the inside we will place the metal weather stripping on the framesame as the opening above, the principle would like to have a door on during the cold months, I may say that we placed a transom over this door to be opened, as there was only one window in this room so that there would be a circulation of air without opening the fire door.

With regard to my suggestion to have ladder from the roof of the porch at the girl's end the matter was first taken up with the principle who wanted it operated from the window in the vestry on the ground floor. The ladder would be in a horizontal position when not in use, and in the event of fire it would be operated from the window, the principle says that he would not have a portable one kept inside the building for use in the event of fire, the height of the roof of the porch from the ground is 10 feet, and there would be the possibility of a jam on this roof as the area is only 42 sq feet. We have also to remember that its possible in the event of fire to have to carry out the patients from the infirmary.

Your obedient servant,

Sdg. Roderick Grant.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have had some correspondence with Mr. Grant, the Inspector of Construction, at the new St. Phillips School in regard to the fire escapes and exits thereto. After receiving your letter of the 28th ultimo I gave instructions that the exit doors should be made to open outwards and these directions are being carried out.

I would point out, however, that on the girl's side of the school the exit to the fire escape on the second floor is through a staff bedroom, and that from the first floor through the girl's infirmary. At both these exits Mr. Grant suggested that an inner door should be hung opening inwards to make the rooms more weather proof during the winter. I wrote stating that the object of placing the exit doors to open outwards would be defeated if another door were to be placed at the same exit opening inwards, and I enclose a copy of his reply.

I am of the opinion that it would be a dangerous precedent to allow the placing of a door to open inwards at fire exits, and while Mr. Grant suggests that the exit at the other end of the passage on the boy's side could be used as the public exit, this will only apply on the first floor as there is no means of communication on the second floor. The only alternative would be to put metal weather stripping on the frames of the doors referred to, and after all this is really only a makeshift.

Another point taken up with me by Mr. Grant was that the fire escape on the girl's side ended on the roof of the porch below from which there is a drop of 10 feet to the ground. His suggestion was to have a ladder from the porch roof, and I pointed out that this was undesirable as it would afford ingress to the building to mischievous boys. The last paragraph in his letter suggests that this, when not in use, will be in a horizontal position and could be operated from the vestry on the ground floor, and this arrangement, of course, pre-supposes that someone would always be available in the vestry to let down the ladder. I do not like any of Mr. Grant's proposals to correct the original defects in planning the fire escapes, and I should like to have an expression of opinion from you.

Yours truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Graham,

Replying to your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the fire escapes at the new St. Phillip's School, I note that you have arranged to have the doors open outwards.

I have looked at the plan and think that the fire escapes for this building are well planned, when you take into consideration the number of pupils that are to be accommodated. When no storm door is used the only alternative to keep out the cold is to use weather stripping around the doors, and you may arrange to have this provided.

With reference to providing access to the ground on the girls' side of the building, this fire escape was not carried to the ground as it was thought that it would be a convenient place for mischievous boys to enter the upper floors on the girls' side of the building, and it was considered that if a suitable ladder of the proper height was kept at that end of the building that it would work satisfactorily in case it was required.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit my report on the work done by the contractors The Wyndals Construction Co., Ltd., on the erection of the St. Phillips School from Nov. 12th to Dec. 6th.

The heating contractor has completed his work on the heating installation, including the covering of the boiler and the steam mains in the basement. We have made arrangements that he will have the boilers cleaned when we have the water pressure in the water system completed. He has installed a heating coil in the pump house. We are now building. It is our intention to use soft water in the boiler when the boilers are cleaned as we have approximately 250 gals in the tank.

The plumbing contract is now completed except for the installation of the sink in the scullery. This will be done when the plumbers come back to test out the water pipes and fixtures when the water system is connected up.

The carpenter work on the finishing is 90% finished except for the building of the rafters, which was started on the Monday today.

The painting work inside the building is well advanced with the barring on the walls in the corridors except for the staircases. I estimate that the painting work is 80% finished.

The electrical contract will be finished about the 13th instant when all the fixtures will be installed.

We have installed a Delco light generating unit 110 volts, D.C., of 1500 Watt capacity.

The laundry machinery is set in place with hot and cold water connections made to the machinery, also the necessary drain connection to the sewer.

I would report that we have the well finished to the required depth, having a water reservoir of 8' deep with a flow of approximately 600 gals per hour.

The contractor is building the pump house over the well to house the pressure tank and I expect the work to be far enough advanced this week to allow the plumbers make the installation for the water supply.

All the metal ceilings throughout the building is covered with the painting complete.

I may say that it is not decided yet whether power is to be used to run the laundry machinery, the contractor cannot complete the installation until the decision is made.

Dear Sir:

I have not received any answer to my letter of the 10th Nov., dealing with the doors on the fire escapes and ladder at roof of porch at the girls end.

I would draw your attention to the plan of the 2nd floor where it shows the partition wall between the girls and boys quarters, there is no opening provided in this wall as it was intended to have a complete separation between the boys and girls, this separation could be just as complete if there was a door placed in this wall at the stair landing for access to the girls dormitory with a special lock that could be opened only with a key from either side by the guardians. In the event of fire in the dormitories there might possibly be some trouble at the fire exits at one or other of the dormitories which would cut off the means of escape. By having a door as mentioned it would act as an alternate means of escape should any of the fire escapes be blocked up during the time of a fire. I am taking an extreme view of the situation, apart from this door being valuable in the case of fire, the Sisters could make use of it when cleaning the dormitories, without having to go around by the staircase. Sir:

I received your letter of the 19th November with reference to the power to be used to operate the laundry machinery. I would recommend that these machines be electrically driven from an economical standpoint as well as being the most convenient to suit the space available. The Principal is very anxious to have it run this way as it will be easier for the Sisters to operate when starting up than it would be with a gasoline engine. They could not start the engine up themselves and there would not be a man there all the time. We could install another unit of the Delco plant now installed, which would make the electrical capacity 3 H.P. enough to run the laundry machines, pump and dough mixer, if it is your intention to have one installed. I would recommend that you install another unit of the Delco plant of the following type, 110 volts, D.C., 1250 watts. The batteries now installed will be sufficient for the additional unit.

If you install a gasoline engine it will require one of the capacity of 6 H.P. This will take up more room with the cooling; it will also use up more gasoline and it is not very convenient to drive the dough mixer, as the belts would be run through the corridor. If you install mixer it will be of one sack capacity and it would take 1½ h.p. The laundry machines would not be run at the same time as the mixer. The mixer should have a meter attached.

You will have to supply a gasoline storage tank of 300 gals. capacity for either an extra unit or engine if used. It would take 1½ H.P. motor to run the laundry machinery. Again, if we put in a gasoline engine we will have to use a counter shaft on the laundry machines as we have to place the machines close to the south wall to give all the room possible in the laundry room. I may say that the radiators are placed on the ceiling in this room which makes it necessary to use a counter shaft to run off the line shaft.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott:-

The question of power to operate the laundry machinery which it is proposed to install in the new St. Phillip's Indian Residential School on the Keeseekoosne reserve is now being brought to my attention. I understand that the machinery is being supplied by the contractor, but the question of power to operate it has not been settled.

In discussing this matter with Mr. Sharpe, who is supplying the lighting plant, he states that to expect the existing plant to operate this heavy standard laundry machinery would be out of the question, but suggests that another unit be added to the lighting plant, which would operate with the same set of batteries. By adding this unit it would do away with the using of the batteries for the operation of the laundry equipment, as it would be operated from the two generating units.

This means of supplying power is the only one that is practicable, especially in an institution where there are only women to operate the laundry machinery, and besides, we have not the space in which to install a gasoline engine.

I should be glad to have your authority to install an additional unit to the plant already on the ground, at a cost of $413.00, fob. Kamsack, installed. It will also be necessary to install a 1½ H.P. motor for this unit, at an approximate cost of $120.00.

I enclose herewith a copy of Mr. Roderick Grant's letter on the subject, which may be of interest.

Dear Mr. Graham,

Replying to your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to the power for the laundry machinery at the new St. Phillip's School, I would ask you to arrange for the installation of a 6 H.P. gasoline engine to operate the laundry machinery. This engine should be installed in the machinery room, as shown on the plan and connected to a line shaft passing through the wall and belted to the laundry machinery.

For your information I would point out that the two Delco generators as suggested by you would have a capacity of 2500 W., which is equal to 2-2/3 H.P., rating the generators at 80% efficiency, which is the highest rating you can give to a generator. As it requires 5 H.P. to operate the laundry machinery, you will see that the generating plant falls considerably short of generating sufficient power. I would also point out that it requires considerably more than 3 H.P. to start the laundry machinery, as it has been found by experience that when the washer and extractor are filled with clothes it takes at least 8 H.P. to get them under way. The gasoline engine where we have to generate our own current is the most economical and satisfactory arrangement.

Sir;

Re-connections from soft water tank to boiler

Sir;

Re- Extra work on pumphouse.

The estimate to build the pumphouse did not include the laying of a concrete floor nor the drainage from the floor. The excavations for the pit to place the pump was done when the ground was frozen, this work was not started until the well was finished as the well is located inside the pumphouse. The floor of the pumphouse is down lower than the floor of the machinery room 4' and the floor of the pit for the pump is down 4' lower than the pumphouse floor. We had to go down with the base for the pump so that the suction lift would not be more than 21' 6". We put a floor drain in the pumphouse and connected same to the boiler room drain. The drain is required in this floor as it will be necessary to clean out the pressure tank when it becomes water logged.

This work was done during very cold weather. It was not until the 29th of Nov. that the well was finished when a start was made on the building of the pumphouse, all the gravel had to be heated for the concrete.

Sir,

Extras on pumphouse

We had to put an extra ply of V joint and two ply of tar paper on the inside walls of the pumphouse above the concrete walls. This had to be done to protect the water system from freezing up as all the concrete work was done in very cold weather and the ground was frozen at the time we worked on the concrete. It was hard to heat the building to keep it above freezing point. The connections for the heating is taken off the end of the 2" main in the machinery room so fire had to be maintained in the boilers to keep the pumphouse above freezing point. It meant that more fuel was burnt to help out the pumphouse, the connections being made at the end of the steam main made it more difficult to heat the room while everything was cold. This is been overcome now as the frost is out of the walls. We also put 3 ply of tar paper under the rubberoid roofing.

The electrical for the pumphouse was not included in the estimate.

Yours Truly,

ST. PHILIP'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The new school had not yet been completed, but the Rev. G. Brouillet, Principal, expected it to be ready by about April 1st. This is a splendid building and good work should be accomplished.

The Rev. Father explained that he needed horses and cattle at once, so as to be in readiness when the children arrived. He claimed that good Ayrshire cattle could be purchased locally.

He also felt he could not proceed without a barn and outbuildings, but I pointed out to him that the barn in connection with the old school could be used for the present, and the old school utilized as a store house. However, a barn should be erected in accord with the new school as the old one referred to is poorly constructed and belongs to the Roman Catholic Church.

A. J. Hamilton

Inspector of Indian Agencies
Mr. E.A.W.R. McKenzie,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Re our conversation of the 13th instant I beg to say that I am quite anxious to open the school on the first of April provided the furnitures have arrived, so far the chairs office desks dressers are missing and we have no word about them also the battleship linoleum for corridors, staff dining rooms and kitchen are also lacking as well as battleship linoleum and brass nosings for stairs.

Now I believe it is the use of the Department to give a certain amount of help to a starting school I beg to ask if you know what amount it is the intention of the Department to use in starting this school? The Department will readily understand that we cannot start the school without horses and a few milk cows, the horses are immediately wanted for wood drawing with harness and a set of sleighs.

At his last visit here last fall Inspector Christianson promised that a telephone line would be erected in the course of this summer and also that the school land would be fenced. I hope appropriations have been made at that effect. Now I must through you advise the Department that the Electric system is insufficient, the house has been already without light for a few days once and now again there is a threat of the same thing happening. We cannot risk to be without lights with the school on. I believe the Department could be advised as to the best plans by the Inspector of construction.

Trusting this will be agreeable, I remain dear sir,

Yours truly

(Sgd.) G.Brouillet,
O.M.I.

I must note also that I received no answer to my letter of Feb. 3 about the bread mixer which is absolutely necessary for the school opening.
Sir:

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter from the Principal of the new St. Phillip's Indian Residential School, which was forwarded to me by the Indian Agent, in which he points out that the furniture, etc., that was ordered for the school has not yet arrived. I think it would be a good idea for the Department to follow this matter up.

With regard to the Principal's request for horses, cows and agricultural implements I may say that I have this matter in hand and have been in communication with the Agent to see if he could locate a four-horse team, sound and suitable to the requirements of the school. He is trying to find such an outfit at the present time.

I would particularly draw your attention to the Principal's remarks regarding the electric lighting plant being insufficient. Immediately on receipt of this letter I communicated with the Delco Light people, represented by the Bruce Robinson Company, and informed them of what the Principal had to say. They at once expressed the opinion that there was nothing very much wrong with the plant, but as they could not afford to have a statement of that kind made they sent a man up there at once and I am in receipt of a telephone message in which they inform me that the trouble was caused by some trifling matter of wires being crossed, a thing that anyone should have been able to detect. There seems to be a feeling in a great many of our schools that any trifling thing that goes wrong all they have to do is to call up this office and make a complaint. I think if we had the right type of men managing these schools we would probably get much better results.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,

Sir:-

With reference to the new building at St. Phillip's School on the Keesekoonse Reserve, it appears to me that the building has now reached the point at which the services of the Inspector of Construction could be safely dispensed with. The building itself is completed and I do not think there can be any necessity for keeping Mr. Grant there to inspect the furniture on arrival. I have received several trivial complaints from him recently regarding the equipment made by the Western Manufacturers in Regina, from which it would appear that he is voicing the complaints of the Principal and the Sisters rather than spending his time in the interests of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir:

In opening this school I wish to disclaim all responsibility in case of accidents in a fire as we are very improperly supplied with means of fighting a conflagration. We really have only the chemical extinguishers on which we can rely in case of a fire starting; the pump we have is only rated at 400 gallons an hour which is an maximum it is automatic but starts only at 15 lbs. pressure, when it hardly reaches the top floor, not the ceiling. If then a fire would start in the roof we would have to let water run till the pump would start running, and we would then have water coming at the rate of 400 gallons an hour which it will be easily seen is insufficient more especially as the electric system is also insufficient. The plant produces only one third of the voltage required for the different lights we have in the house and in winter we certainly will very often have to use more than one third of the lamps what means that when taking into account the pump that alone takes one fourth of the plants production we must understand that we will have then to have the plant going the most of the day to equalize the charges. If then the plant would happen to be out of condition (what has happened already twice) we would cut off lights and water, and consequently in a very awkward position to fight a fire.

I have already called the attention of the Inspector of construction on this, and he admitted that he himself thought two plants of that size, and one pump double the size or two pumps were really needed and added that he had made preparations for a double unit and a double pump by the side of those already in operation. I hope that if he has made this suggestion to the Department it will be listened to, and then I would feel that we have a fair chance to defend the life of the children given to our cares.

With the hope that this will be understood

I remain dear Sir.

(Sgd.) C. Brouillet, O.M.I.

With regard to the wire for fencing the school property, $175.00 provides ample wire, and this is all I think we should supply. The fences at other schools are built by the staff, and why should we pay labour to build a fence here? Any Principal can say that his staff is not sufficient or that the children are not big enough. If the grant of $175.00 had been made for wire and the Department insisted on it the fence would have been built. Had it been Mr. Hendry, at Portage la Prairie, or Mr. Rhodes, at File Hills, or in fact any of our Principals who do business in a businesslike way, we would have had this work done and there would have been nothing more said about it. I believe that the fences at the schools in the Onion Lake Agency were built by the staff. I am not sure about this, however, as there may have been some direct correspondence with the Department on this subject. If it is your desire that gates should be supplied for this school, and that I should hire men to put the fence up I will see that this is done; personally I am opposed to it. I may say that in July this Principal made the statement to Agent McKenzie that one of our Inspectors had told him it was the policy of the Department not to use willow pickets for the purpose of fencing school property, but to use cedar posts. The Inspector in question was spoken to about this matter, and denied absolutely that he made any statement whatever about the posts, and added that he did not see why willow posts should not be used for this fence, as they are used by all the farmers in the district, in fact we are exporting willow pickets from this very reserve for fencing elsewhere. I fear the Rev. Principal here has not the right idea as to what is expected of him.

I will have an estimate made as to the cost of levelling the ground around the school buildings, which I think, of course, is a proper charge against the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:—

I have your letter of the 9th. instant, No. 117-3-5, informing me that the Rev. Principal of the St. Phillips Indian Residential School recently visited Ottawa, and represents that they are unable to provide the labour in connection with the building of a root house, as the boys at the school are all small, and you advise me that I may expend an additional $250.00 in this connection. I regret that you have authorized this additional expenditure. The Principal at this school is just as well able to provide the labour to build a root house as they are at any other school where we expect them to do some of the work. At File Hills, the Principal, who is no differently situated than the Principal at St. Phillips, undertook to build a root house with the help of his own staff and the pupils, and the result is that he has a wonderful place at no cost to the Indian Department. His idea is to provide and do as much as he possibly can himself, carrying out the Department's repeated instructions that Principals are to do as much of the work as possible. At the C. of E. School on the Peigan Reserve, the Indian Agent estimates the cost of the material at $85.00, and the school staff are doing the work, although the situation here is, if anything, more difficult than at St. Phillips. Also at Morley, where we are just beginning, and the pupils are small, a root house was built without employing outside labour.

It is disappointing, to say the least, to have a Principal go to Ottawa over my head, when he has been instructed to do certain things, and have these instructions annulled. Of course, any Principal can make a case if he is not interested in getting the work done as economically as possible.

Sir,

When calling at Ottawa on July the 7th I was unable to see you because as I understood you had not yet returned from your trip west, so I spoke on a few subjects to Mr. Sutherland who was to report to you on your return, and let me know your decision but as I have had no answer as yet, I take the liberty to write to you hoping for a solution on—

1st The lighting system I then mentioned that it was insufficient I must emphasize on this because I now see that in the short days of winter we will have to return to the old system of coal oil lamps—presently with only a few lights or in the evenings we have the generator going 8 hours every day and one day every week 11 hours to bring the batteries to the required strength.

Now I believe you will understand it better by figuring—

The generator is rated 1½ kilowatt, the pump is supposed to use one quarter kilowatt but either the generator is overloaded or there is something wrong with the generator when the pump is not in action registers 10 amperes and then the pump is working 2 amperes only.

The pump is now working 5 hours a day using the difference between ten amperes and two amperes—8 amperes consequently the generator produces 80 amperes a day and the pump uses 40 amperes the difference that is 40 amperes is what we have to pay for light at present with every thing going right it is sufficient but when we have to have lights for less than 8 hours every day it will mean running the generator for 16 hours every day with one oiling (as it is self-oiling it has to be stopped to put new oil in) which soon ruin it.

Dear Sir:

Re: St. Phillips School.

A lack of water in the well, the use throughout the school of unnecessarily large lamps, and the generating unit in a dirty condition and being operated at 70% capacity, comprise the causes of the complaints of the Reverend Principal of the above school.

Following your complaint to us last Wednesday, I wired our Chief Pump Expert to meet me at Kamsack and together we made a complete and detailed survey of the Water and Lighting Systems.

We found that the water supply in the well had dropped to four feet below the "low level" given us by the Inspector of Construction, a result, so the Principal informed us, of the very dry fall. We found only four feet two inches of water in the well, or approximately Seven hundred and seventy-nine (779) gallons.

This level being three feet six inches below the normal low level, prevented the Pump from drawing sufficient water to build up full pressure in the tank.

The Electric Plant was in a very dirty condition and the mixing valve was being operated in a position whereby only 70% of capacity was realized. This was explained to the Principal and he promised to operate it in proper position.

We checked the lamps used and found only one 25 watt lamp
With regard to the pump, you will note Mr. Sharpe states that it was mechanically O.K., and that the main trouble was a scarcity of water. The Principal should have been able to detect this. He found the plant in a very dirty condition and the mixing valve being operated in a position whereby only 70% capacity was realized.

Mr. Sharpe has been called upon to incur a great deal of expense in connection with this matter, that should never have been necessary, as there was nothing wrong with the plant, other than that it was in the hands of a very incompetent man.

I am having the lamps replaced with smaller ones at an early date, and am also arranging for the lowering of the pump, and having the supply line from the tank to the main feed pipe changed from 1" to 2". Mr. Sharpe informs me that in about ten days' time one of his experts will be in the Kamsack territory, and that he has had instructions change the pipe mentioned from 1" to 2". This man will also change the lights to conform with Mr. Sharpe's recommendation and will supervise the lowering of the pump, etc. I may say that Mr. Sharpe informed me today that he thought the pump should be lowered to a depth of 7 feet instead of five feet, as stated in his report, and I am so informing the Agent, whom I have instructed to have the work of excavating done.

In conversation with Mr. Sharpe he expressed the opinion that the Principal was not trying to make the plant work satisfactorily, as he had his mind set on a duplicate system, and nothing else seemed to satisfy him, but after reading Mr. Sharpe's report you will see that this is not needed. The present plant is ample, and the Principal is either not trying to carry out the wishes of the Department, or he is not competent to manage the plant. It seems too bad that we are called upon to carry on such lengthy correspondence in connection with this new school. This Principal has wanted so many changes made, entailing a lot of extra work, and even then he is not satisfied and I am told does a lot of talking. I think that perhaps a letter from the Department, couched in strong language, might settle this matter once and for all. I have no objection to a man's drawing attention to things that are wrong, but when it comes to laying the blame on the Department for everything, when in reality the blame should rest on the one who is making the complaint, as is the case in connection with the lighting plant, I think it should be stopped.

Yours very truly,

W. H. Graham,
Indian Commissioner
Dear Mr. Scott:

On October 17th., you wrote me with reference to the condition of the lighting and pumping plant at the new St. Phillips Indian Residential School, at Kamsack, pointing out that the Rev. Principal had advised that they were generating 8 hours a day, and once a week 11 hours, and that he feared they would have to supplement the lighting with coal oil lamps during the winter. He also stated that they had practically no water pressure and that he was worried about the danger of fire. On receipt of your letter I sent for Mr. Sharpe, Manager of the Delco Light Company for the province of Saskatchewan, and drew his attention to the contents of same. Mr. Sharpe told me he was much concerned about this matter and that he would go to Kamsack himself and look into it. He arranged for their Chief Pump Expert, who was in Manitoba at the time, to meet him in Kamsack for the purpose of looking into the water system at the school. Before Mr. Sharpe left he told me he was quite satisfied in his own mind that the lighting plant which had been installed was more than ample to meet the requirements of the school, basing his opinion on the results obtained at dozens of other schools and institutions throughout the country where their plants had been installed. However, I thought it well to have him go up there, and when you read his report, which is enclosed, you will note that the plant was called upon to furnish twice as much light as was absolutely necessary. In the whole school he only found one 25-watt lamp, the others, with the exception of two clusters of four each, ranging in size from 40 to 150 watts. This is, to say the least, absurd, and the Principal comes in for censure by the Department for making a report of this kind, and it shows that he knows very little about an electrical plant when he would load it up in this way. Mr. Sharpe can be thoroughly relied upon, and his statements should not be questioned.

With regard,

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a letter received today from the Principal of the St. Phillips School regarding the walls in the stairways. While returning from Keesekonse reserve today I called in and find that in certain spots of the wall in the stairwells the plaster is loose on each of the floors and in both stairwells. The plaster in several places is bulged so that it is forcing out the upper burlap mould. If this work could be proceeded with right away, could I have your instructions by telephone or wire, please. I could then have it done while the plasterer is on the ground.

With regard to the locks of the doors, this applies throughout the building, they are a nicely finished lock but evidently not very strong. The biggest trouble is with the knobs, these are on an adjustable bar on which the knob is fastened by means of a set screw which does not hold, the inner mechanism is also weak several parts of some of the locks being very easily broken which makes it almost necessary to renew the whole lock. I believe Mr. Wyndel the Contractor should do something over these as I am informed by the Principal that he had to change one or two of the locks even before the building was completed.

Sir,

I beg to report that from Wednesday morning Feb 27th to yesterday we have had to use coal oil lamps and draw water from well with pails on account of plant being out of order.

On Sunday Feb. 24 the plant refused to work. On Monday I examined it and found the coil in the starting switch to be burnt. On Tuesday I started to "unsack" to try and get a new one. There I met Mr. Schneider (Bruce & Robinson's expert) who was on his way to St. Phillips for the overhauling of the plant and the erection of the new pump. He immediately phoned his company for the necessary part, and had the promise that we would receive it next day when it did not come.

On Friday we received a 32 volt coil that we had to return as our plant is a 110. The order had been given right and the bill was right but the expedition wrong.

On Monday March 4th we received the right coil, and on setting it we find the breaker assembly was also out of order.

On Tuesday March 6th Mr. Schneider phoned for a breaker assembly and had the promise it would be there (in Kansas) on Wednesday we had a team to get it, and again on Thursday but it did not come.

On Saturday morning Mr. McKenzie the Indian Agent phoned and asked for one to be sent in his name; this we got on Monday.

On Tuesday March 12 after setting the plant to work Mr. Schneider found there was a ground in the system, and located it in the pump house's main where a wire had been left without insulation by the electrical contractor.

Mr. Schneider states this was the cause of the whole trouble as there was 2 amps escaping by this ground which he finished repairing on Friday March 15 at noon. Since then we have electric lights and water from the 200 gallon hour pump. Mr. Schneider could not erect the new pump as it came without cylinder.

Now on October 17th the Secretary of your Department was advising me that Commissioner Graham was being instructed to send an expert to this school, with a view to determining just what was wrong.

In place of an expert, the man who sold the plant was sent. He had to acknowledge the insufficiency of the pump but advised reducing the lights so the plant would be sufficient. This advice has been followed, and the lights exchanged. The result is that the house is not in darkness and reading is impossible in the most of the house.

I believe the new lamps would be sufficient may be if the fixtures installed by the contractor according to specifications would be replaced by drop cords, which would not be so nice to look at but at least would furnish us with light. This is the advice of Mr. Schneider. The expert who states that as the ceilings are painted drab color and the fixtures are mostly ceiling balls it is impossible to have enough light otherwise with the actual lamps.

It is for the Department to decide but certainly something has to be done.

Trusting this will be remedied I remain Your obedient

Sir:-

I beg to draw your attention to the fact that there has been considerable correspondence in connection with the building of a drying room at the St. Phillips Indian Residential School in the Pelty Agency at Kamsack, and an amount of $1200.00 was allowed for this purpose. What I had in mind was that the vacant space at the rear end of the building should be walled in and roofed to conform with the rest of the building, and that this space should be used for the drying room. I sent sketches to the Principal of the buildings that we proposed to erect there, and they all seem to be satisfactory, with the exception of the drying room. Below I shall quote an excerpt from the Principal's letter which is self-explanatory,-

"About the drying room, I beg to say that I do not believe we could use steam for drying if the drying room was in the proposed location because though our heating plant has ample power it has not the level to heat at that far corner. In fact I had a radiator burst last winter in the room adjoining and had to have it replaced. Besides, I would like to use that addition as night watchman's room and I would like to have the drying room built over whole end of the building as proposed last summer with the entrance thereto from the night watchman's room. With the drying room on the level of the second storey and a door out to the roof drying wires could be placed between the drying room and the main building as well, and the steam could be used from the plant we have, otherwise we would have to have a stove with a chimney, because of furnace not being low enough to give heat in the proposed room because of the lack of level."

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the schools in the Pelly agency, which were inspected by Mr. Hamilton.

I note the Inspector speaks of the removal of four large posts from the classroom of the St Phillips school. I presume this was done with the authority of the Department. I have no record of it here. The matter of a flag and flag pole for this school has been attended to. I could also have the necessary fencing done in front of the school if the money is available.

You will note it is the desire of the Principal to have classes in manual training at this school. This perhaps should be carried out to a small degree, but I do not think we should put in expensive equipment and make it a main feature of the training. I should prefer to have the boys taught something about cattle, poultry, gardens, etc., as this would be of much more benefit to them than any manual training they would receive at a school of this kind.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

In connection with the drying room at the St. Phillips Indian Residential School in the Pelly Agency, for which an item of $1200.00 was placed in the Estimates by me and allowed by the Department, I may say that this was for adding a room to the present building by walling in the vacant space at the rear corner, and roofing it over to conform, of course, with the rest of the building, and I find after getting an estimate on the work that it can be built well within the amount allowed.

Another plan, namely, to put an addition on to the whole back end of the present building and bring it up another story, running clothes lines from there to the main building and making a walk over the roof. I think this is absolutely out of the question, and that the only feasible plan is to build the room that I had previously recommended. As Mr. Mayoh, our foreman, is there at the present time erecting the outbuildings I would recommend that this work be gone on with on the lines I have suggested, and I should be glad to have the Department's sanction in the matter.

I should be glad to have an immediate reply.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have just received a letter from the Indian Agent at Kamloops forwarding a request from the Principal of St. Philips Indian Residential School to be supplied with 3 tins of chemical powder for re-filling 5 Pyrene fire extinguishers.

I think this request is most unreasonable and have so informed the Indian Agent and directed him to tell the Principal that the Department cannot and will not bear every small expenditure in connection with the administration of Indian schools. What he is asking for will cost only a few cents and is an item which he should purchase himself.

I trust the Department will support my attitude in this connection. I am of the opinion that in many instances Principals of schools ask for too much, but the Principal of St. Philips School, in particular, is constantly calling upon the Department to bear expenditures which, in my opinion, should be borne by the school authorities themselves.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir,

Regarding G. Hutchinson claim for compensation, this man got a splinter in his hand which did not appear to be at all serious, when this happened I do not know, he showed me his hand somewhat inflamed and said that it had become worse while working with it. I told him to see if the Sisters could give him something to dress it with, this is the last I knew about this hand until I received a copy of the letter from Mr. Stewart. I have no other notification that he thought he had any claim, his wages were 45¢ per hour for a ten hour day, when he got $5.40 he was working overtime.

On making some inquiries from the other men, I hear that G. Hutchinson went over to Barton's and they did some amateur doctoring there, including tying it up in a poultice, so tightly that he complained that it had stopped the circulation. Insofar as I know the splinter was a small matter such as many men get who are not used to such work and whose hands are therefore soft.

Yours respectfully,

To the Commissioner,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Regina, Sask.,

Dear Sir,-

I hereby make formal application for compensation for an accident which occurred to my right hand while working on the building of the machine shed at the St. Philips Mission on the Keeseekoose Indian Reserve in the Province of Saskatchewan. I was forced to leave the employment on the morning of the 5th day of July, A.D. 1929 by reason of such accident and entered the Kamsack Hospital on July 9th, 1929 at which place my hand was operated on by Dr. C. E. Tran of Kamsack, Sask. I was kept in hospital until the morning of the 17th day of July, A.D. 1929 and I am informed that I will be unable to work until at least the 5th day of August, A.D. 1929.

I therefore make application for payment of compensation for a hospital bill of $30.00, a doctor bill of $35.00 and payment of wages at the rate of $5.40 per day from the 5th day of July, A.D. 1929 until the 3rd day of August, A.D. 1929, or for such further time as I am unable to work by reason of such accident.

I might say that I was employed by Mr. J. Maych, of the Department of Indian Affairs, to whom I gave verbal notice of the accident to my hand.

Gifford Hutchinson

Dear sir:

Re: St. Phillips School - Kamsack.

We are attaching invoices covering changes made in the pumping system of the above school.

Originally a shallow Well Pump was installed based on the water measurements given by the then Inspector of the Construction, whose statements assured a constant low level sufficient for shallow well pump operation. However, a lack of precipitation in the subsequent year so reduced this water level that it was necessary to change the shallow Well Pump for a deep Well Pump to reach the lower water level.

This we have done as per instructions and have allowed the full price originally charged for the shallow Well Pump.

The pipes connecting the supply tank to the two inch mains were of 1 1/4" size, and were part of original installation made by the building contract plumber. They were obviously decreasing the supply of water to the building, and have therefore changed them, making connections to supply line the same size to the tank.

While there a "ground" was discovered in the wiring, and our electrician had to test all lines to locate it. He corrected it, and also found that weatherproof wire had been used in some of the conduit instead of rubber covered wire. This he changed too.

Before leaving he overhauled the Plant thoroughly. No charge has been made for this.

Fire Risk. The Dormitory—Particularly the one used by the girls.

The question of fire risk in a dormitory perhaps does not come under my supervision but I feel certain that those in charge will forgive me if I intrude upon something that does not actually belong to me. My excuse is that the lives of these children are all too precious for officials in any sphere to hesitate and examine the bounds of his jurisdiction too closely where the safety against loss by fire is involved.

PLAN OF THIRD STORY OF BUILDING.

Solid Wall—No means of passing through.

Outside Fire escape

Inside stairway GIRLS.

Inside stairway BOYS.

My point is that if this building caught fire in the north wall then these little girls would be cut off from escape. The fire that would destroy the utility of the inside stairway would also destroy the outside fire escape or make it impossible to use.

The solution seems to cut a doorway between the two dormitories. The sisters' room could be again placed to guard it from entrance except when danger threatened. Build a doorway between the two rooms and build a small bedroom for the sisters. This would safeguard the matter and would also make possible the elimination of the fire escape on the north wall altogether. Trusting that you will forgive me for trespassing but I have a deep interest in these children and would like to see them safe guarded.

Yours faithfully,

Condition of Classrooms (Ventilation, light, etc.) The classrooms are well lighted and ventilated. These two items are fully modern and are a credit to those in authority. I would like to thank the Commissioner for having the pillars removed from the classroom in this school. The mechanic in charge made an excellent piece of work and the rooms are in good condition.

Classroom Register (Is a careful tally made morning and afternoon?) Sister Veronica takes charge of the recording the tally daily. It is systematically attended to and was in perfect order.

GENERAL

(Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the classroom activity generally and offer any suggestions for improvement.)

The pupils are well behaved but are not willing to speak out. There is a decided tendency to whisper the answer and that not loud enough to secure the meaning. In a residential school that should be eliminated without very much difficulty.

Fifty per cent of the time the children are occupied with either farm or household duties. This arrangement seems to be satisfactory.

The writing, spelling and drawing were receiving adequate attention. In the primary room, under the charge of Miss Samson, it would be as well to introduce more of the primary type of activity. Singing little simple action songs, drawing, handwork and modelling has a tendency to relieve the strain of study upon the little people just beginning school life. Of course this really entails having a trained primary teacher in charge of this room so as to get the right primary spirit.

The class-room work is divided into junior and senior grades. Miss Samson is in charge of the junior room and doing splendid work. Sister St. Veronica has the senior grades and is an exceptionally good teacher. The roll calls for 50 pupils, and the attendance is excellent. The grades range from Grade 1 to Grade 6. The junior room has the beginners and Grade 1, and marked progress could be noticed in the work done by these pupils.

Sister St. Veronica requested that a cupboard be built in the class-room where she could keep the books and papers required for her work. At present there are no cupboards, so that her request is quite within reason.

The sewing room is in charge of Sister St. Veronica and the work seen was well done. Here the children are taught to patch, darn, and do the ordinary sewing required in a home.

The kitchen and laundry work is also supervised by the Sisters and I found each department in splendid condition.

Fire drill was observed, and the children were able to get out in two minutes. All fire apparatus appeared in good condition.

Honoured Sir:

During the past school year we several times presented our requests to the Department asking for Battleship linoleum for the floors of our chapel and two corridors, stair treads, etc., for stairs and landings, maiden varnish and paint for interior repairs. Each time we received a refusal. During your visit to our school, in the summer of 1928, our Reverend Father superior, in the absence of the Principal, has spoken to you of Battleship linoleum, and you have been so kind as to favour our request. This is why we take the liberty of presenting our request anew, and addressing it to you personally, hoping you will kindly take it into consideration.

Our western floors receive only a coat of oil when the house was built and are now in urgent need of repair; the asphalt floors of the basement are new we believe, in condition to receive their covering of paint; the radiators and pipes need re-bronzing; and much of the woodwork of lavatories, infirmaries, etc., needs a new coat of paint, if the house is to remain clean and sanitary.

In the answers received from the Department it was suggested that the Reverend Father Breullette, principal, secure these things with the money of the per capita grant. Now this is clearly impossible as the per capita grant is just sufficient to meet the ordinary expenses and the more so this year, that the Reverend Father has had hundreds acres of new land broken, in which work he has received no help from the Department. Besides, if we have been well informed, the things we ask for, Battleship linoleum, varnish, paint, etc., are furnished to the other schools, then why should St. Philips be deprived of them?

We shall await your answer to find out if you the exact list of things needed.

Sincerely hoping that our requests will find entire favour,

we remain,

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to report that I visited the schools included in the Pelly Agency during the month of September last, and noted conditions at each.

ST. PHILLIPS R. C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This school is situated at the east side of the Keeseekeose Reserve, and is under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, with the Rev. Father Brouillet as Principal. There are 53 pupils enrolled, twenty-five boys and twenty-eight girls. I visited the classrooms, and noted that the pupils were well clothed and had a clean appearance.

I went carefully through the building, and found it clean and tidy throughout. The building itself is in very good condition, being practically new.

There are stair fire escapes at each end of the building, which are in good shape and provide a means of exit from each floor. Fire extinguishers are provided on each floor, as well as hose attached to the standpipes. This equipment is in good condition. I am informed that regular fire drill is being given to the children. The water supply is obtained from a well, which provides sufficient for their requirements.

Dear Sir,

In answer to your request regarding the deficiency of the heating in the drying room at the St. Philips Indian School, I wish to advise as follows:

I visited that point in company with a heating expert and we examined pipes and radiators and find that the radiator that had been installed in the drying room was of ample size to heat the room but the pipes leading thereto and also to several other radiators in that section of the building are so connected that there is too much wet steam delivered to those particular radiators thereby causing excessive condensation in the radiators and the drying room being one with two exposed walls and situated in the north west corner of the building, the radiator freezes and bursts owing to this excessive condensation. This condition can be remedied by changing the flow of steam pipes which supply these radiators delivering to the radiators dry instead of wet steam thereby reducing condensation to a minimum.

The present radiator is useless, it will have to be replaced, and the change made in the pipes as mentioned above. If this is done it will overcome the radiator freezing and bursting.

I would undertake to do this work supplying all material and labour for the sum of Ninety two Dollars, ($92.00)

Trusting that this is the information you require

Sir:-

I recently received a voluntary communication from the Regina Representative of the Delco Light frigidaire, with reference to the lighting plant which was installed by them at the St. Phillips School in the Pelly agency, advising me that an expert recently inspected the installation and reports that the present plant is very considerably overloaded.

The original connected load was 2500 watts, and a 1250 watt plant with batteries was sufficient to operate this load satisfactorily and was therefore installed. The report states however that the size of the light bulbs has been largely increased with the result that the connected load is now nearly 5000 watts or double what was originally provided for.

This question of overloading was taken up at the time the plant was installed, but it is clear that the authorities at the school have ignored the warnings which were given them that the plant could only satisfactorily operate if discretion was used in the use of light bulbs.

I think this information I have received from the Company should be in the hands of the Department, as, while the generator has been overhauled by the Company and is operating in a first class manner, it clearly cannot be expected to carry the load which is now being forced upon it. In the meanwhile, the batteries are being worn out and as a result will require replacement this fall.

Your obedient servant,

Following up my verbal report to you the other day about the light plant after being out of light and water for a week I have had a new Armature installed in the generator but it does not work satisfactory because of the batteries being worn out. Dinner - Meat, fish, eggs, potatoes, gravy, bread, and a dessert of pudding or dried fruit, tea and milk.

Supper - Hash, soup or pork & beans, a dessert of rice pudding, dried apples or prunes, or honey, bread tea & milk.

Lunches are served to the children both morning and afternoon at recess. This consists of bread with brown sugar or honey.

The laundry machinery appeared in good working order, and the children receive excellent training along this line.

I am enclosing herewith a report on the various schools in the Pelly Agency inspected by Mr. Hamilton.

Sir:

I have your ll of the 2nd instant, with reference to the water supply at the St. Philips Indian Residential School. I have reviewed the departmental files in this connection, and I find that, in addition to a well which the mission dug, to a depth of 40 ft., in 1926, there is the well in the basement of the new school, which was prepared by the Wyndels Construction Company, at a cost of approximately $1700. This well is 6 ft. in diameter, approximately 37 ft. deep, circular, with concrete walls and an 8" brick wall from the bottom of well to the quicksand. At that time, Mr. Roderick Grant, Inspector of Construction, put down a 6" test hole and struck water at 24' 6" below natural grade. The location of the test hole was 20 ft. from the south side of the machinery room on the left side elevation. The elevation where the well was actually dug was approximately 5 ft. lower than the test hole.

The Inspector of Construction reported, in January, 1928, that extra work was necessary on the pump house. The floor of this building is 4 ft. lower than the floor of the machinery room and the floor of the pit for the pump is another 4 ft. lower still. At that time, it was stated that the base of the pump had to be lowered so that the suction lift would not be more than 21' 6".

In October, 1928, the Bruce Robinson Electric Limited, of Regina, when making a report regarding the pumping of water, stated: "The water level in the well is 3' 6" below what was stated to be the lowest level. If dry weather continues it will likely drop further. The pump hole should be excavated to a further depth of 5 ft. and the pump set that much farther down to provide against a continuance of the shortage of water. The supply line from tank to main feed pipe should be changed from one to two inches."

Commissioner Graham, on September 29, 1929, wrote that the Reverend Principal wanted permission to dig another well, about 30 ft. deep, presumably outside the building. This was authorized, and a few weeks later the Department paid an account in favour of G. R. Hutchison, of Kamsack, for digging the well 20 ft. deep, at $1.00 a foot and 27 feet at $1.50 a foot. Dear Sir,

In answer to your honored of August 2nd I beg to say that we have had a night watchman in this school for two years now, but as we have no punch clock I cannot vouch for his faithfulness in making the rounds and I would ask the Department to supply us with one without delay.

For the repairs and improvements the first and absolutely important is the replacing of the power plant; this plant has always been inadequate to the work it had to do and we had complaints from the doctors that our children's eyes were suffering from strain from too poor light, and besides the outbuildings are not lighted none of them, we have to use 600-l oil lanterns in barn with the danger of fire that follows.

The second is cement paint for the basement the cement is going in dust which is unhealthy for the children and I would suggest that the Department would have it painted with cement paint.

We have had the promise of telephone service from Kamsack every year but when is it coming? I must advise the Department that the buildings should all be repainted on the outside delay will cause increased expenses.

The setting of the building has caused breaks in the plaster in the stairways but this can be repaired with very small expenses.

For the farmer-instructor's house I am quite satisfied to wait as he is using jointly with the night watchman a building just across the road that is owned by the Oblate Fathers.

Trusting these at least the two first repairs and the punch clock will be granted.

I remain dear Sir Yours Truly

Sir,

Enclosed is a letter from our teacher thanking the Department for the certainly nice books sent to us. I entirely concur with all that is said, but must add that I wish we could have more use of them; they would be real nice in the long winter evenings, and our children would certainly derive great benefits from them were they able to use them, but books are not much use to blind men, and this is about what our children are today with the present state of our lighting plant. Over a month ago I wired that we were without light, since then we have been able to patch up the old plant enough to have a little of very costly light, we were willing to put up with this as we were given to hope that we would at last have real light in this school too what would be as nice as new, we have always had a very poor light being forbidden to use powerful enough bulbs the power being inadequate (in fact an ordinary good farm plant). In these conditions the hope of having real light at last was worth a sacrifice, but it seems as if we were after all to have only the same power in the generator we are going to have and books will be only for the long days of summer when books lose their interest for children.
