Memorandum

It was urgent that a new plant be installed to provide proper lighting for the school, and in the purchase of the Lister plant we have obtained the highest standard of equipment in this line and at the lowest possible price.

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General
Due to the big increase in price a night letter was sent to the R.A. Lister Company of Canada Limited, Winnipeg, asking them to advise by wire the cost of a Lister plant for the School. On the following day a telegram was received quoting a price of $515.00. An order was then placed with the Lister Company for their plant, the same being in stock ready for immediate delivery. The Indian Agent was also advised that the order had been placed with the Lister Company, and he was instructed to arrange for its installation.

The following telegram was received from the Dickson Electric Company of Winnipeg on January 26th:

"Order for Delco Lighting Plant Fifteen C-1 Model for St. Phillips Mission Pelly Agency Kamsack and letter confirming instructing us to bill your Department and signed by Eben W.R. McKenzie your Agent received by us January sixteenth. This plant shipped from Toronto same date and is on way to Kamsack. McKenzie informed through our dealer at Kamsack in November as to Customs tariff ruling on equipment for Indian Reservation. We have wire and letter from Commissioner Customs dated January twenty-first confirming. We are billing your Department accordingly unless you can have Customs Department authorize purchase under Tariff Item four naught nine dash naught. If permission obtainable invoices will be altered to farm price. Wire reply."

A reply to this telegram was sent as follows:

"Delco plant St. Phillips School not required."

With reference to the two plants I would say that the Delco plant is manufactured in the United States, and at the present rate of exchange and duty the price is considerably higher than a plant of the same capacity as manufactured by the Lister Co. The Lister lighting plants are manufactured in England, and of course, at the present time benefit by the exchange and duty. I may also say that the Lister lighting plant is a much superior unit than that manufactured by the Delco Company.
January 26, 1933.

Memorandum: Mr. Buskerde

Replying to your memorandum of the 27th with reference to the lighting plant required for the St. Phillips School, I beg to give you the following information.

On September 20th the Indian Agent reported that it would be necessary to renew the lighting plant at the St. Phillips School, which consisted of a 1-1/2 K.w. Delco generating plant. On the 25th of September a memorandum was forwarded to your office asking for the names of firms from whom prices could be obtained for this plant. These names were received and the Agent instructed to obtain prices, and to have the installation made by the firm quoting the best price.

On November 20th a telegram was received from the Agent stating that in getting quotations they were having difficulty establishing whether this would be considered a farm plant or otherwise. The Agent was then advised that the lighting plant should be heavy duty type.

A letter was received from the Indian Agent on November 22nd advising that to date the only price he was able to obtain was from Johnson's Garage, and that they had quoted a price of $672.00 for a farm type plant, and asking whether he would proceed with the installation. Owing to the urgency of having the new plant installed, due to the fact that the old one had completely broken down, he was wired on November 26th to proceed with the installation.

On the 22nd of this month a telegram was received from the Indian Agent as follows:

"Advised today by Delco Agent that Customs have ruled St. Phillips School not entitled to farm price previously quoted for lighting plant engines. New quotation Eight Hundred and Seventy-five dollars, which is in excess of amount authorized. Please wire instructions, plant badly needed."

Sir,

I beg to confirm wording of a telegram phoned from the station today:

"Forward immediately copies of all correspondence your office regarding order Delco plant also advise as to any verbal understanding."

In this connection, I beg to enclose office copies of all correspondence dealing with this plant up to date, which could I have returned, please when recorded.

Quotations for this plant were called for on Wed. 7th, and as the only one that could handle it, Johnson's Garage Kamsack quoted a price of $672 plus $67. For parallel boards installed. This price of course was subject to the plant being admitted on a firm plant basis. Earlier in the season Mr. Smith of the Dickson Electric Winnipeg passed through and at that time unable to give Johnson's Garage a definite price but promised to make inquiries and advise which was never done. I later received the Department's telegram authorizing installation after my advice by letter, and about the same time was called on the phone by Mr. Marston, Inspector at Regina that Kamsack Board of Trade were submitting a proposition for lighting and to wait for a time before ordering if the present plant was running.

This was done during which time I had made several requests of Mr. Johnson to take up and get a definite price and early in January as the school were again having trouble I told him to order the plant at the price quoted. My next information after a week or so was from him that the price was more owing to duty and the same date I notified the Department by wire receiving on the 24th inst. the telegram re latter plant.

If there is any fault in price quoted it would lie entirely with Delco people in Winnipeg as Johnson's Garage was going on what information they had from them.

I have also seen since two parties in Kamsack who would undertake installation as soon as is known what is to be installed.

Sir,

I beg to advise that the St. Philips School have had the hot water boiler in the kitchen burst in addition to one end of the kitchen range where the pipes connect into the water front. This burst one night as soon as the heat was sufficient, due to a block in the pipes from alkali. It has rendered one end of their double stove useless and the remaining portions of the boiler has been removed as also the pipes leading to the water front. They are cooking for the whole school on the one end which is almost impossible and are without the hot water tank in the kitchen. The principal states that he is afraid to put in another boiler there as it might go the same way but does ask for a new range.

The range that was installed by the Department is a double range made by the Gurney Oxford people, it is called the John Bull Army Range, No. 9 No. 27 A.

Can a replacement of this range with the double water front, or rather one at each end be made at the school?

Your obedient servant,
